reviewText:
One of my all time favorites.
To sum it up, it's an apocalypse Zelda where you explore the mystical land of Detroit as Red Arthas, a.k.a. War.
You get touched inappropriately by Vulgrim who is the Genie to your Aladdin, and also by the Watcher who is the Navi to your Link.
You mission is to find the president's stolen rubies, restore Satan's nemesis to his older glory and to find the true meaning of Christmas. The usual.

reviewText:
Pros:
- Cool story. You're a horeseman who's so strong that you serve as the law, balance, and order between Heaven, Hell, & Earth.
- Awesome Hack & Slash gameplay. The combat looks great and feels satisfying.
- Progression: There's lots of gear, combos, special moves, upgrades, etc. to unlock.
- Good graphics, cutscenes, and voice acting

Cons:
- Puzzles are required to reach the next area.
- Puzzles are required to reach the next boss.
- Puzzles are required to reach another puzzle.

reviewText:
The game may show a large amount of mechanical similarity to God of War, that is really where the comparison ends. Darksiders drops you into a post apocalyptic nightmare of a world that is an amazingly organic blend of Heaven, Hell, and the modern world. The game contains many beautifully designed levels that have you running down city streets one moment, and fighting in a Hell spawned cesspool the next, with one flowing beautifully into the other. Character and monster design leave nothing to be desired either, with wonderfully detailed nightmares and angelic warriors coming at you from all sides. This game definitely has the eye candy taken care of.

As far as the mechanics go, as I said, think God of War and you've pretty well got the idea. You're going to collect souls in order to level up. You'll learn new skills, get new toys, and those toys will need to be leveled as well. You'll run around unique, artistic maps solving complex puzzles. Combat is largely combo based versus multiple opponents, with multiple weapons to choose from. One of the amusing additions to combat is the ability to use just about anything in the environment as an improvised weapon. Street signs, street lamps, cars, you can use them all as either projectiles or beating implements. When the boss fights come up, you'll be working to beat them down to a context specific cut scene finale. If you enjoyed the GoW's gameplay style, you'll feel right at home here. And honestly, there is something to be said for that. The familiar mechanics mean that there's no time wasted figuring out how the game works, and more time spent actually playing the game.

Darksiders can be challenging at times, particularly some of the boss battles but the best advice as always is to persevere and you will find the solution. If you can overcome those minor issues then Darksiders has much to offer with a good storyline, many hours of gameplay, and some of the best action sequences you are likely to see.

Though influences from other games are clear to see, Darksiders still manages to excel on its own merits. If you're looking for an action/adventure that will keep you busy for hours then there is no need to look further.

reviewText:
In 2010, the Earth is going to be hit by some meteorites. These are not just rocks, but the actual armies of Heaven and Hell, ready to fight each other in an epic battle. Mid in the fight, another man falls from the sky: The Apocalyptic Horseman War. He does not fight for any side in the battle, he is just there to keep the balance, but there is one problem. The Horsemen are only allowed to interfere when the 7 seals are broken. And nobody broke them. War gets teleported to the fiery council, who go into court with him because he broke this rule.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=274593426
He tells them that he has gone to earth because he thought the seals were broken. The fiery council gives him another chance to get rid of his guilt, by killing The Destroyer, the one who started the battle between heaven and hell. So War gets sent back to earth, 100 years after the apocalypse.

The gameplay is a typical Hack'n'Slay. War is badassily strong and gets to fight against a lot of enemies at once.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=274593415
His sword swings hit many enemies at once, and there are other weapons to be aquired with other abilities. The battles feel good and fluid, the finisher moves are brutal and the blocking/evading works great.
But there is more than just fighting. The game provides levels and riddles that make it feel like the result of hot sex between God of War and The Legend of Zelda. The riddles can get really hard at times, but not frustratingly hard, so the game does not get boring.
There are a lot of collectibles in the open world, and they also help War, like the Abyssal Armor. There are 10 pieces to find, that are pretty well hidden. If you find all pieces, you get one badass armor.
Sadly, the programming is weak at times and lets the game crash from time to time. There are also some bugs, like falling through the ground (happened to me 4 times). Good thing that there are enough checkpoints to make up for such annoying bugs.

The grafics like a bit comic-like. The characters look extremely packed with muscles,
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=274593438
blood squirts en masse, the bosses are huge and monstrous. The environment is very variable, from the destroyed remains of New York over a forest to a huge desert. The light effects look great and the textures are detailed.

Huge, aggressive sounds of orchestral rage are violating your ears in this game. The music fits extremely good with a game where you play as The Apocalyptic Horseman War himself.

reviewText: Very underrated game in my opinion. First of all, there aren't many good slasher games on PC, thus this one is already worth buying it. The graphics is not next gen as it was port from the consoles, but the game still looks nice due to wonderful level designs and pretty character models. The story itself is very interesting to follow, plus there are some collectibles to find - thus  the full game completion will take some 20 hours. I recommend it to everyone who likes action games with giant bosses, lots of puzzles and badass main character.

reviewText:
I'd started playing this game on several occasions... the first time the game chewed me up and spit me out before the end of the first dungeon... the second time I reached the first Boss, took a hammering a few times and then took a long break... but the story and the gameplay really intruiged me, so I came back a third time and was able to stay the course this time. Despite my earlier misgivings, I had an absolute blast and thoroughly enjoyed playing Darksiders... a few people have said it is an underappreciated game, and I can understand that.

The player takes on the role of War, one of the 4 horsemen of the Apocalypse, who has been summoned to earth under the impression that the Apocalypse has begun, but when he arrives he finds that the 7 seals required to summon the horsemen are intact, and that his 3 companions have not been called... moreover the demons and angels have wiped out man and continue to fight in the remains of the Shattered Earth. War is accused of breaking the law and siding with Demons, so he sets out to clear his name.

As a Christian, with an interest in endtimes fiction, I personally found the over-arcing story to be very interesting... though I can see that the in-game story could have been so much better than it actually was, perhaps down to publisher's decisions.

The game is most often compared to Legend of Zelda, and God of War (with a touch of portal thrown in too)... Having never played either LoZ or GoW I did not find the game to be derivative, except for the portal elements, so that colours my opinion of it. I did find combat to be frustrating at times, and it was this that initially put me off... but restarting a couple of times gave me the chance to become more familiar with the enemies and more experienced at fighting them. There is quite a significant degree of button mashing, but no amount of hammering on the same keys will keep you alive unless you learn to survive against some of the nastier enemies.

The game does have some of the best boss and mini-boss battles of any game I have played, with particular favourites being: The Jailer; The Griever; An Ashworm; The Stygian; The Broodmother and The Destroyer, to name a few.


On the down side there is a lot to get through between boss battles... with travelling through areas between the main hub and the dungeon, then completing the relevant dungeon including numerous tough enemies and a few nosses (not bosses) and mini-bosses... to finally face the dungeon's boss. Also, the dungeons themselves are linear, the puzzles are usually spelled out for you by means of an introductory cut-scene (which I'm used to from the tombs in Assassin's Creed 2), and they were almost always solvable using the piece of equipment or special skill that you'd just acquired... furthermore you'd often acquire something in the dungeon that would then be the key to fighting the boss. I've played and enjoyed a lot of linear games, so I really don't mind that so much.

The voice acting is a bit of a mixture... Mark Hamill is brilliant in the supporting role as The Watcher (simultaneously holding War's leash, and acting as an in-game hint system), while some of the other cast were not as great... a few people have commented that the actor voicing War was especially bad, though I never found him to be quite so... I guess I just accepted War's personality as his portrayal and I certainly never felt his delivery jar me from the game.

Another particular highlight for me was when War was able to summon Ruin, his horse, and the couple of big fights that followed... some brilliantly epic gaming in my opinion.

reviewText:
Darksiders is underrated game. Why? I don't know.
Many reviewers describe this game as God Of War clone. Even if it's true, I see nothing wrong with that. On that point, are all the shooters clones? Are all games sharing same gameplay mechanics clones? I mean, yeah, it have similar gameplay at it's core, but in my opinion, it's more correct to put this game in that particular subgenre of hack 'n' slash-action-adventures, rather to call it clone.

So what is that game about.
You can find about the plot in wikipedia or something. In that type of games, the plot plays secondary role (atleast for me). What I want from that type of game is good, solid gameplay. And Darksiders have it. The game's story is decent enough to keeps you playing and thats more than enough for me.
The short version: you play as WAR - one of the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse, summoned to restore THE balance between the good and evil.
For the most of the time, you hack, slash, climb, pull, shoot, solve puzzles, open chests, fight bosses...What more do you need?

The gameplay is solid and polished. The combat and platforming feels and plays fluid. I've had some difficulties with the shooting, but nothing gamebraking. The puzzles are challenging, but not too hard.

The art is comic-styled with the typical hyperbolized models of the characters, armors and weapons, which makes the world of Darksiders epic and badass.
There are some RPG elements, but nothing special. Collect souls, buy upgrades, movements, gear, etc. The score and voice acting are on decent level, but fits well and helps the game to feel even more epic.

So if you love God Of War, Dante's Inferno, Devil May Cry, Prince Of Persia, Legacy of Kain, you will love that one too. It plays right, feels right, looks right, it's a good, solid and polished game.

And FFS, people, PLAY IT WITH GAMEPAD! I can't imagine how can you play that sort of games with keyboard and mouse! You will hardly enjoy the game without a proper controller. It's designed to play that way. Some people call it bad port, i call it bad peripheral choice.
I've played it on Xbox360 and it plays the same. So nope, not a bad port at all.
Had some problems with my Logitech Rumble Pad controler though, but putting x360ce make it work like charm.

8.5/10

AMAZING GAME WITH NO DLC AND STUFF !!!

Ok this one sat in my backlog for a good bit ,so the other day i decided to give it another go and try and finish it. Man this game is so darn good.The story is so good and this one is pretty long also ,but well worth the ride.If you like the battle systems like Devil May Cry or Remember Me give this one a go.

The puzzles and action fighting is a good mix and a good challenge.The level designs are amazing and fun and real neat.The fights may be a bit repetitive but still rewarding.The crazy thing this game is pretty long for a game without DLC or addons.Ive been reading many would like to see a Deathinitive Edition or a Warinitive Edition but i say dont fix what isnt broken.

The voice acting (Mark Hamill as The Wather) is also real good also so is the music

If you dont own this one id say pick it up and if you do blow the dust off it like i did and give it another shot till the end ,im sure you will like it once the full story is told !!

Truth i would like to see a movie or cartoon with this game,id go see it :) Amazing story ! Check it out !!

reviewText:
INTRODUCTION:
I got Darksiders because I was interested on the rather unique theme. Once I started playing it, I quickly found myself being oddly familiar, despite being my first playthrough. Then it dawned on me, the game played like other more popular Action Adventure titles such as, but not limited to: God of War, DMC, Zelda, Prince of Persia, Portal etc. At first I was skeptical about the similarities but still found Darksiders to be a fun game in it's own right.

War, one of the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse has landed on Earth triggering a full scale conflict between Heaven and Hell which utterly disrupted the precious Balance that dominantly prevailed for eons. Hated by Hell, condemned by Heaven, War now walks the Earth in an attempt to clear his name.

PROS:
+ Familiar but still Fun Gameplay: -Taking multiple inspirations from other titles, Darksiders takes the best of the best features and aspects of those titles and mashes them up to make a Frankenstein monster type of game which is unique unto itself. This game deserve more attention than what initially got.

+ Atmosphere and Sound: -Sound assets are magnificent, scenery are breathtaking and character art are wonderful built. They all come together to make a very immersive and beautiful post-apocalyptic Earth.

+ Graphics to Framerate Ratio: -Being a copy paste console port, does leave the game a bit weak in terms of graphical fidelity, poor texture quality, weak special effects and limited animations are blatantly visible but it does benefit older and more outdated PCs. The 1080p support does make it more vivid and sharp than the console counter parts.

+ Puzzles: Taking inspiration from the Zelda games, Darksiders does feature a lot of puzzle solving, involving different skill sets and items that the player acquire. The puzzles are simple enough to not be frustrating, yet delivers a certain level of complexity that makes them satisfying to solve.

CONS:
- Controls: -Being a console port, this game was clearly designed to be played using a gamepad rather than the mouse and keyboard. Attempts were made to integrate it better to Keyboard controls but the player will be left rather frustrated for the most part.

- Limited Graphical settings: -This speaks for itself, the game hardly has any options to change graphical fidelity. If you find yourself using a lower-end PC and FPS drops occur, you probably won't be able to do anything about it.

- Poor Story and No character progression: -War is not the most likable video game personality you will encounter, the story does not develop on the main protagonist either in personality or traits. He will have the same expression and demeanor from start to finish. As the Fallout games say, War never changes."

- Restrictive maps: -Lets make a checklist on what being a Horseman is all about. 1. Have a horse (albiet a bit late in the game but CHECK) 2. You can fight in said horse (CHECK) 3. You have a place to ride your Horse (NOT CHECK). The game gives you one or two maps where riding Ruin (your horse) viable
recommended:
you'll find yourself fighting on foot through small and cramped areas not being able to utilize the glory of mounted combat.

CONCLUSION:
GOOD GAME
hoursPlayed:
it takes the best mechanics of other games and places them into one and making a very fun and enjoyable experience.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Like my Reviews? Follow my Curator's Page:

http://store.steampowered.com/curator/6861651-Miyumi%27s-Review-Corner/"

reviewText:
Still looks good thanks to a excellent art direction. I orginally played Darksiders on PS3 but didn't complete it. On the PC, it still looks and plays great. It's not perfect but it absolutey fun to play. I've heard it described as Zelda for grown ups and I think it is an apt comparison. In each section you have to obtain a new weapon or tool that will allow you to proceed to the next area or get back to that one spot you couldn't previously reach. It also has some very simlar weapons/tools such as the hookshot, a boomerang, a shadow world over world. There appears to be a fairly deep combo system but I was ok playing a button masher extravaganza and only learining a couple of the combos.

My only negative, which may not be one for some, would be that it overstayed its welcome by just a bit. By the time I was 26 hours in, I was ready to get to the end of the story (which is still pretty good by the way)

I would defintily still recommend it and I look forward to playing as War in Darksiders 2. Based upon recent news thre is still a chance that I will get to play as Pestilence and Famine.

reviewText:
Darksiders is a great action game that combines the hack 'n slash gameplay with a unique and engaging storyline.

I confess that at the beginning the game did not hold me, but past the first few hours it became very good, the gameplay is similar to other games in the genre but it has its originality, with good combat mechanics, mixed with clever puzzles. Graphically the game is ok, the sounds that are the highlight with good effects and a great soundtrack, and a flawless voice acting.

The plot is another strong point, well worked and unique, which involves aspects of Christianity and has great characters. War, one of the 4 horsemen of the apocalypse and the playable character is without a doubt remarkable and captivating.

Although the combat gets better on the joystick, there are many parts where you need to aim and I found difficult when I had to be quick, so I started to play on keyboard + mouse. There also a problem with achievements, I noticed in the middle of the game that some don't unblocked. Other than that, I can only recommend!

8/10

I honestly had problems writing this review. With my numerous attempts at writing a decent introduction I found myself thinking about this game much more than I should, considering it is just a dumb, unambitious hack 'n' slash title...

I remembered how this game started a series which never reached completion, as THQ's bankruptcy halted all plans for future entries after the second one. Should we be sad about it? I mulled over all those opinions about War's journey being a calque of successful story of Kratos from God of War. How funny is that? There are so many H'n'S games, GoW did not start them nor was it the best game (/series) of this type. I thought how many people will even read this review, considering that everyone who wanted to own Darksiders already has it, either cursing or celebrating it (or maybe doing simply nothing...?).

Oh? I accidentally wrote something akin to an introduction. Sweet!

At the beginning, I stated that this game is dumb and unambitious. While this is technically true, as the game never overstepped its bounds with its design, there is no reason to label it as bad". Quite the contrary

reviewText:
After almost 20 hours of continuously playing I'm finally done. This has really been that one game, that has finally revived my hunger for actually playing games. Where to start, you start as a warrior named war (hence the pun :D) fighting against 2 factions, heaven and hell to regain balance. As most people I started by reading some reviews, then I stumbled across this one review which said '' please don't play this game on easy, you'll regret as hell'' so I followed his advice, took normal, now that I'm done I highly regret not playing on apocalyptic (hardest difficulty). So please, don't be as foolish as me and play this game on apocalyptic mode and just enjoy it. Now to some pros and cons

Pros:
- The story is just amazing IMO, you're a horseman, you're one of the 4 horsemen who serve as the law, balance and order between Hell, Heaven and Earth. I really recommend you see all cutscenes and just follow the story and never miss a shot, cause man you'll regret like hell.
- The voice actors are just amazing, the way they talk, how they talk and just everything, there's always something new to expect in each cutscene.
- Dialogue is amazing, not just the voice actors.
- The best way to put the combat is that it's hack and slash, use combos, any kind of combos you desire, buy, explore and slaughter.
- Terrain and environment is good, it ranges from different areas and ''worlds'' to explore, everything from new york (if I'm not mistaken) to huge deserts where hostile threats are yet to be found.
- As the game progresses you'll obtain new items, upgrades, special moves, and character upgrades (different tokens, health and wrath)
- Creativity is shown, the economy here isn't the typical gold, or dollars, here you deal with 3 different type of souls, money1, wrath2 and health3. Blue1, yellow2 and green3 ( Number behind indicates which colour is for which thing.)
- Graphics are good. cutscenes are good, nothing bad which I've noticed
- Music is quite good, it fits the situations you're in perfectly, it's basically this Synchronisation that's highly appealing and creates this dramatic effect.

Cons:
- Game might crash when you alt+tab and enter back to the game, so if you must alt+tab, remember to save right before you do.
- too many puzzles at certain times, but look at the bright side, if you like challenges and like to exercise your brain, this will be no con to you.
- Some bosses are just too easy, it isn't overwhelmingly easy, but they just don't feel as hard as they should have ( might be cause I played in normal and not apocalyptic, silly me :C)

Conclusion: I would just like to say that I had a really good time playing this, at times I got shivers down my neck and goose bumps by the story alone. This is one of the best games I've played in a long while, I got this constant thrill and at times my adrenaline was just soo high. If you are considering on purchasing this, stop hesitating and just buy this. It's really worth it, if you are a tf2 trader, go to market and buy the franchise pack for 5 keys, it's worth every single penny, I promise. that's all I had to say.

Personal score 10/10

reviewText:
I once wrote in a Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 review that it definitely has the most zealous prologue in video game history. Truth is, there is another game that can dispute this title; that is Darksiders. It literally starts with an apocalypse. And though it isn’t maybe as brilliantly directed as Castlevania’s reboot, but how can you beat such dramatic premise? The judgment day had come; four horsemen of the apocalypse were summoned to the Earth. You play as one of those four — War. He is big. He is muscular. He wields a gigantic sword. He is constantly enraged. And finally, he is voiced by Liam O’Brien, who once told you that you are not prepared, and who always performs like he’s totally ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off and has had a three day lasting constipation. Arriving on Earth our hero finds out that he is alone. That it was all someone’s ruse, because the final seventh seal was not broken. War goes on a series of angsty battles against various demons in pursuit of the one who’s responsible for this, and finally ends up fighting a gigantic boss.
And this is the tutorial part, so it’s supposed to be easy, so the protagonist ends up being imprisoned by The Charred Council, mysterious creatures “overseeing the balance” while looking like big stone head statues. He cuts a very shady deal with them for a bit of “detective” work on Earth, finding the deceiver who killed billions of humans and started out a war between angels and demons, lasting more than one hundred years. Yeah, for some reason War has been kept for so long, and now he’s weakened, so good bye, overpowered abilities from the prologue, you won’t see them ‘till you are fully levelled-up and nearly through the game. I hope, at this point you are totally getting that this is a story that says “♥♥♥♥ logic” and bursts out in a series of delirious, bizarre events, that actually are quite entertaining. From the point of style it’s obvious lowbrow; in case you didn’t know game’s creative director was John Madureira, a comic artist best known for his work on Uncanny X-Men series. So, yeah this game is power-fantasy, and it’s filled with testosterone like a gym locker room.
A notable thing about this game is, that back in the day, when it was released, it most usually was described as Zelda wrapped up in Warhammer or Warcraft, maybe with the added scent of God of War. And it’s true, of course. But the real game’s sibling was always Castlevania, series which shifted to explorational gameplay being inspired by Zelda. There’s really no point in my nitpicking here, other than an obvious intent to define most of the Zeldas as metroidvanias. So, yeah it has a rich ramified big world filled with puzzles, bosses, minions and secrets (maybe even too big, especially if you talk about those portal section near the end, ugh). And it’s open to explore in virtually any order, but in reality to access certain areas you’d need special abilities or keys and that means sticking to the script, being a good horseman of the apocalypse and going where you are told to. That means, player will rarely be stuck somewhere, and that’s good news, because there's a lot of good stuff. The scope and scale on which Darksiders operate isn’t just big, it’s enormous. What starts as a pretty mediocre one-button-mashing slasher set in though very interesting scenery of post-apocalyptic Earth being torn apart by demons and angels turns out to be much more. Of course, no one would take away your severed heads, buckets of blood, game’s bread and butter, but there’s more to that. Riding a horse, and fighting on a horse (hey, you’re horseman after all)? Check. Shooting stuff with your pistol, with big angelic gun or while riding a gryphon in shoot-em-up section? You got it. And then there’s more and then some.
One can argue that game lacks innovation, but at the end of the day it doesn’t matter. Vigil took what they can here and there, but they didn’t lack self-irony and they took it knowing how to use it to create a game that is good entertainment.

reviewText:
Darksiders is a truly epic and immersive experience. A dark and twisted take on the Biblical Apocalypse, that features an awesome storyline, wrapped into a visually modern hack-and-slash style game, but with many time-tested gameplay mechanics still in place.
The game will take newcomers at least 12 hours to beat, and along the way it delivers a very well distributed amount of great storytelling, hardhitting combat (which has finishing moves that you simply can't get enough of), and challenging puzzles. At no point does one thing or the other become boring, and this might be Darksiders' biggest strength.
It might have been developed for consoles and then ported to PC some time later, but don't let that fool you. The controls are still good, and it doesn't take much time to get used to playing with a keyboard and a mouse. All keys are rebindable.
The game might crash on occasion, so remember to save often. But this is a minor concern, and Darksiders is definitely a game to keep a lookout for during the Steam Sales.

reviewText:
Darksiders is a game that piqued my interest several years ago when it first came out. Inspired by a genre I really enjoy but taken in a grittier, and more combat oriented direction. Which sounded like the best of both worlds. For a first outing the games designed at an okay level.

At a basic level the game is fun, and functional. Animations are nice, your character is responsive and combat is very rarely unfair. Though that level of fun is drained by decisions both small and large that really inhibit the game from obtaining its true potential.

While combat is fun at a basic level, it never really evolves. Basic enemies never challenged me to change my attack plans. Even when mechanics like blocking were added to enemies, launching them still bypassed it, which launching is part of the basic attack string. While in the air you are functionally invulnerable to all but a few basic enemies as well as enemies have no aerial attacks or grabs of any kind and as such they generally waddle in to get hit along side your launched target and die.

There are heavy and miniboss enemies that are littered throughout the game, but they are either forgettable and unchallenging or downright unfair and cheap. The unfair enemies generally have mistimed attacks that don't feel in line with where you should be attempting to parry. This means it takes far more experimentation to find out if an attack is even parriable in the first place, let alone get the timing right. There's also the problem that attacks really aren't intuitive as to whether they're parriable or not. A miniboss with giant exploding flaming hands can be parried, while An overhead slam with an axe from a skeleton is not.

The game also has issues with targetting. I seriously believe that if you are making a third person spectacle fighter, you really really need to have a good camera. When focusing on a single enemy the camera zooms in extremely close behind your character, so much so that  you can't keep track of opponents behind you or to the side as well as you should. This means focusing for the most part is not what you want to do, as you will take free damage from enemies that you can no longer see.

There's also the problem of what the game decides you want to target. In my opinion hitting the focus button should prioritize the enemy closest to the player first and foremost, then allow you to cycle if you want someone else. This allows the player to quickly swap to the largest threat in their vicinity without the hassle of swapping targets. In the middle of combat I found it frustrating on multiple occasions using my right hand to use the thumbstick to swap between targets. With your right hand also being used to attack jump and evade, there is too much burden placed on you to control both the camera and combat at the same time. Thus I find it very unintuitive.

Bosses are for the most part are boring as well. They for the most part have sequences where you have to use a gimmick or tool you obtained in the dungeon to weaken them just to fight them. This is saddening, as fighting them face to face is what's genuinely fun. Not waiting X seconds to throw a bomb to knock the boss to the ground while running around in circles. Some bosses are actually genuinely fun, as they have no gimmicks attached to them, and that is where the game shines. But they are few and far between.

For the most part the tools you get are pretty nifty, they are fun to use and modify combat in a genuinely interesting way. With the exception of the horse, it just doesn't fit into the way the game is designed and feels shoehorned. The game has a very claustrophobic closed in feel, where you are progressing through tunnels and buildings, not wide open fields. Where you actually use the horse is in the one area it was designed for. That area is just designed for the horse, there's no reason for it to be so large, except to give the horse a purpose. One that really doesn't mesh with the rest of the game. You can't ride the horse inside, combat on the horse is unwieldy and riding it feels more like driving a tank than a horse. I'm not a fan.

The dungeons themselves have a great aesthetic design. I like how they look, I thoroughly enjoyed my time inside each one, as they all have their own flair. But the game, really holds your hand whenever you enter a new room as it forces you into a cutscene that slowly pans from object to object in the order  you have to use them. The puzzles are basic as it is, to also show me where each piece is and the order to use it in turns each room into a really boring series of fetch quests. Grab a bomb from location A, bring it to location B.

The writing is mixed as well. While the main character and the only female character fall flat and into generic stereotypes. One being dark and edgy, while the other a perfect example of a damsel in distress. The side characters however are genuinely interesting. For example, the maker you meet called Black Hammer is by far the best character. He is not flat, one dimensional and his entire backstory is not revealed in one sentence. The same can be said of Samael as well.

The game could have really shined if it had more development time. At a basic level the game is functional and can be fun if taken in small quantities. Though it gets repetitive really fast, from both a combat, boss and puzzle perspective. If you really enjoy this genre there is fun to be had. Otherwise I would highly recommend the second game in this series or another game series altogether.

reviewText: Put together an action game, with an adventure based in exploration and dungeon beating, an apocalyptic fantasy setting and the result is one of the most enjoyable games I have played the last few years. The plot is nicely done, though a little confusing, but the characters and mythology are well created. The gameplay and mechanics are easy to learn and the action is very gore, which would feel stereotypical if not for the mix of genres. The only flaws might the graphics (not bad but should have been much better) and some level design (extremely long and annoying dungeons). This is a franchise I would definitely want to keep playing for a long time.

reviewText:
Just recently finished my run through Darksiders; I must say I was very pleased with the experience.  The game reminded me of a cross between Legend of Zelda and God of War. The plot of the story isn't necessarily anything to write home about, but the actual atmosphere of the game is superb. I found the environments in particular to be highly immersive; each area has its own unique theme. The non-player character models, including their animations, are extraordinary.

The combat isn't particularly evolved and the game itself isn't exactly challenging. I personally played on Apocalyptic and would recommend others do the same. There were a surprising amount of puzzles, invariably utilizing some recently acquired gadget. These items are often necessary for collectibles, but rarely are required in areas beyond which they were designed.

If I had to summarize my experience with this game I would say this: It starts very strong, but begins to struggle in the end. There are enough awesome" moments that keep you engaged through the ~15 hours but the repetitious challenge/puzzle formula
recommended:
and anticlimactic ending make for a mediocre finish.

I still recommend the game. It was quite an enjoyable adventure and I'm looking forward to seeing more of this stylish world in Darksiders II.

Awesome game, unfortunately, a lot of bugs and a bad port from consoles
Game review

This game is awesome in:
Story: Greatest story about the four horsemen with an strong plot.
Gameplay: Fluid, rapid, alot of action with possibility of upgrading yourself
Soundtrack: Very emotional soundtrack.
Difficulty: Face a lot enemies and solve numerous puzzles.
This game is bad in:
Bugs: There's a lot of bug, i will list the known ones.
Bad Port: No optimization nor graphics settings.
Repetition: Some puzzles may become boring due repetitiveness
List of common bugs
Crystal Sword: You may get stuck on Twilight Cathedral due a glitch with Crystal Sword, remember to save your game BEFORE getting the swords. There's no fix if you get stuck, only loading your game.
Abyssal Armor: You can't start a new game with Abyssal Armor if you exited game after you get it. You should get Abyssal Armor, quit to menu, then start a new game with Abyssal armor, finally save the game. It's the only way to start a new game with Abyssal Armor.
Achievements: If you load de the game multiple times in a single session, Steam will stop counting your achievements, the only way to solve this, is running the game in Big Picture, then look on your achievements, if they're displaying 0/0, you have to restart Steam to fix, and avoid to load game manually.

reviewText:
This was the first game I have played in years that gave me that same epic feel of Zelda.  I had been really missing the whole dungeons with totally epic boss battles vibe, and Darksiders delivers.  The story is a little odd at first, but I got more into it as the game went on.  My favorite section is fighting when you first get your horse and fight this awesome arena battle and the subsequent sandworm boss -- I was totally sucked into the atmosphere.

Another great aspect of the game is the on-the-fly loading.  I'm surprised no one else has mentioned this, but it's huge for me.   I play games to immerse myself in another world, so I HATE loading screens, and in this game you can run across the entire game world without a single one!  Applause to the developers for that one.

It falls in to the hack-n-slash style of combat with projectile weaponry mixed in for variety.  There's a lot of combos, and it can get a little tedious if you don't force yourself to try new moves.  That being said, each dungeon typically requires you to use new skills to defeat the boss, it's more about switching things up on the smaller enemies.

I do wish more of the characters were a little more likeable, but I get why they are the way they are.  All-in-all, if you loved games like Zelda: Ocarina of Time back in the day, get this for sure.

reviewText:
Darksiders is an action adventure game that while competent, doesn't really bring anything new to the table. It's a mix between a God of War styled combat and Zelda exploration and puzzle solving.

Pros

-Nice combat that gradually introduces new weapons and items to use
-A big world that allows for a bit of exploration
-Good amount of upgrades for both your weapons, moveset and other modes
-Not that many items but they all have their purpose that makes them unique

Cons

-Not enough enemies. In a game where the combat is one of the major elements, it doesn't help when you usually only fight 5 or so enemies at a time. There is also little enemy variety.
-The world is huge but doesn't feel natural. With no towns or relevant NPCs or sidequests, it feels like a giant corridor. There is little reason for backtracking other than getting to chests you couldn't reach before, which you either have to do  every single time you get a new item or wait until the end of the game when you already have every item
-Enemies placed outside of dungeons are repetitive and sometimes a few zones won't even have any enemies at all
-Too easy, both the combat and the puzzles, safe for a few examples near the end.
-Nothing new about any element in the game. All items and puzzles have a certain been there
date: done that" feel to them.\n\nConclusion: I realise that I listed more Cons than pros
recommended: but I still enjoyed the game. It just seemed to be dragged down by a lack of originality and a few amateurish flaws like the overworld's design and the simplicity of both the items
hoursPlayed: their function and the puzzles themselves.\n\nI recomend it to anyone who enjoys this type of game
voteText: unless you're craving for something new and original
helpfulPercent: which darksiders doesn't provide at all. It competently follows the mold of all the elements in most action/adventure games
votesHelpful: nothing more
votesTotal: nothing less."

reviewText:
In six words: a darker and edgier Zelda clone.

Don't expect crazy parkour, stealth sequences or an award-worthy plot: it's not that kind of game.

What you get is a fairly linear action title mixing hack & slash action sequences with environmental (and/or ability-based) puzzles and backtracking for powerups (and at the end, for a bunch of plot tokens) rather typical for its' metroidvania roots and character design closely based on Joe Madureira's art style.

Yes, the game is fairly simple... but you know what? I'm all right with this, because it's also very, very enjoyable for what it is.

reviewText: Reminds me alot of DMC and GoW and a couple of other PS2 games of the genre. At first it seemed a little too simple but as you progress in the game you will find how much variety there is, both in combat and in puzzles. I like how the main character is such a badass and playing as him you can just plow through hordes of enemies. The thing I like most about the game so far has to be the boss fights. You can get really creative while fighting them, dodging their attacks, countering their blows and hitting their weakspots and finally finishing them with a unique blow that often gets pretty ugly. Can't wait to finish this game so I can try out the sequel. The game is great but the one thing that bothered me was the way they layed out the keybindings. I fiddled around with them a bit but didn't quite get them to be as smooth as I would have liked.

reviewText:
This is one of my all time favorites. It lends to the playstyle of a Legend of Zelda game in a bad ♥♥♥ apocalyptic/armageddon setting. The story comes from a comic book theme and it is very engaging and well told. I'm on my second playthrough trying to collect every artifact.

I've recommended this game to all my gamer friends and casuals alike. The character details and artwork are amazing. You start off being framed and accused of triggering earths apocalypse and while some of it can be predictable to some, it takes you on a dramatic and action packed roller coaster ride throughout.

I've only played with keyboard/mouse so I can't offer much input on the Rumblepad/XBox controller issues, but the mechanics of the controls make it very accessible.

Still remains one of my recent favorites in my Steam library and for me that speaks a great deal because few of my games have held my attention for as many hours as Darksiders has.

Review update:
I got to the last parts of the game and those parts are SUPER SH|TTY, so much that it drops my impressions of the whole game down a big notch. It really was great up to that, but the longwinded finale is so tedious and boring that I won't be finishing it and will watch a Youtube video of the rest of the game instead.

Every task no longer feels FUN anymore, they all just feel like WORK, like enduring heavy sack upon heavy sack as an 18th century underpaid dock worker. Ending parts includes a PORTAL device and you all know what that means - super gamey and boring puzzles that are not hard to figure out, only hard to stomach.

Ugh, I'm just now watching the YT vid, showing you have to spend an absurd amount of time backtracking all over previous finished/empty levels, just to collect 7 pieces of some special" sword to stab the final boss with - so happy I skipped it. Even the VIDEOS are so boring I have to skip and fast-forward them. It looks like having to do the Water Temple in Zelda 10x in a row. Or doing the awful backtracking in Metroid Prime 2: Echoes in slow motion. Way to top of the game with the biggest yawn in history.

I still recommend the game

reviewText:
As something of a dark take on Zelda games, Darksiders is an underrated action platformer that never really attracted as big an audience as it probably deserved. It's not without its flaws - particularly as an unfriendly PC port - but the storytelling and combat are good enough to justify the price of admission.

You play as War, one of the four horsemen of the apocalypse. Dressed like something out of Warhammer 40K, and wielding a huge two-handed sword named Chaoseater, War has been summoned to Earth to take part in the final battle between angels, demons and man. Or so he thinks.

When it is revealed that the horsemen were not in fact summoned, War is accused of taking the apocalypse into his own hands and sentenced to death. He successfully protests, and vows to right his wrong, but also to uncover why he was on Earth if he had not been summoned.

War employs a variety of familiar weapons and tools reminiscent of Zelda, but with a twist. The magical boomerang becomes the crossblade (huge shuriken), instead of a bow and arrow War carries a pistol named Mercy, and the hookshot is known as the Abyssal Chain. He also has some magic, but all these play second fiddle to the combo-based swordplay.

Three main weapons are at War's disposal: the aforementiond Chaoseater, a mystical scythe, and a powered fist weapon, of which the sword and one of either the scythe or fist can be equipped at any one time. Tapping the attack button for either begins a chain, and you can incorporate attacks from either of his two weapons at any time. Delaying input for half a second at certain points in the combo can open up new combo moves, usually with a situational purpose such as an area attack, and War can also launch and air combo his enemies if he so desires.

The weapons and tools have upgrades, not just simply increasing damage but adding new combo moves and abilities, such as a spinning airborne slash for the Chaoseater or allowing the crossblade to bounce between nearby enemies. When things get really hectic, War can transform into a big fiery demon for a short amount of time, greatly increasing the power of his attacks and making him near-invulnerable. The only real problem with the combat is that there aren't enough keys on an xbox controller (mouse and keys are not ideal) to map everything, meaning you'll mostly be sticking to two or three favoured items.

Darksiders is a worthy addition to any collection, and clocking in at less than 20 hours means it's good value for money without becoming a drag. The combat is fast-paced and varied, and the presentation while dated is expertly executed. The only real issue with it is the dodgy PC compatability, which you can choose to fix or ignore, and meaning that you'll probably want a controller if you really want to enjoy it.

+ Combat is great fun
+ The setting and story are well conceptualised
- Dodgy PC port

reviewText: This is a fantastic game. I was expecting a cheap God of War Clone, but it's far better than that. For one thing the Horseman War is far more interesting a character than Kratos, whose one-note vengeance act is wearing pretty thin. Great atmosphere, fun combat, very creative puzzles, and some of the best creature design ever. It's a long game with tons of bosses, and they're all awesome looking. New elements are constantly introduced to keep it fresh--grappling hook, horseback combat, and even some Portal dynamics near the end. The biggest criticism is that Darksiders doesn't do anything new, but combining all these great elements from other games so successfully IS something new.

reviewText:
I came in to Darksiders with no previous notion of what the game or gameplay entailed. I was immediately impressed with the gameplay, and the graphics are decent, although the cutscenes graphics are lacking compared to in-game graphics, which can be forgiven for a 4-5 year old game.

The gameplay almost never gets stale, it changes up enough to keep it from getting boring. Even when you have to fight the same mini-boss multiple times they change it up enough to keep it interesting. On normal mode the game seemed easy, so if you are an avid, able gamer, I suggest playing on difficult.

This is one of my favorite games of all time. The puzzles are interesting and the story is good. It reminds me of The Legend of Zelda puzzles crossed with World of Warcraft style graphics, and the combat is reminiscent of slashers like Devil May Cry and hero titles like Arkham Asylum and Deadpool, where grappling an enemy makes the other baddies wait for you to finish.

Completing the game took roughly 24 hours of gameplay on normal mode while hunting down every upgrade, armor piece and treasure chest I could find.

reviewText:
I played Darksiders on 360 when it first came out and at first I was disappointed. The combat seemed shallow and I genuinely thought it was going to be a brainless hack n slash from start to finish... oh how wrong I was.

The best way I can think of to describe Darksiders is as a cross between God of War and The Legend of Zelda. Admittedly, the combat isn't as good as GoW's and the puzzles are better in Zelda, but after playing through Darksiders and thoroughly enjoying it I prefer to look at things the other way around: the puzzles are better than GoW's and the combat is better than in Zelda. It really is a AAA game.

Get past the slow start and you'll find one of the most underatted games of recent years. And you play as War. WAR ffs! How cool is that?!

reviewText:
A very good single player adventure game with a mature and badass setting and lore. The item mechanics is similar to that of Zelda games while the combat is more that of god of war. This is not a bad thing since they have taken some of the best elements we have seen from other games and perfected it. As long as you are not overly critical and expecting something totally new or original you should not get disappointed.

The PC mouse and keyboard controls are even better than the consoles gamepad version since you can now control the camera much more effectively, rendering the occasional tasks of aiming easier as well as less need of focusing the view on specific targets. As long as you map the keyboard layout to your preferences, controls should be precise and combat should be fun and challenging. If you prefer tight gamepad controls, then you can always use a xbox 360 controller.

The graphics and effects are nice and colorful with the limitations of that of the consoles Xbox 360 and PS3. The only setting you can change is the resolution so there are no improvements for the PC in those regards.

reviewText:
One of the best hack and slash games I've played on PC , up there with it's sequel , Darksiders 2. The game features extremely cinematic fighting and , unlike a number of other games like it , does not rely on QTs quite as much with only the occasional B button.

Speaking of the B button , even though this is a PC game , an Xbox pad is highly recommended. Button mashing when it comes to a keyboard is a bit dodgy , even if you are good. This really goes for all hack and slash games since it puts way too much strain on your hardware to make sense using it to smash your foes' faces in.

The storyline will pick you up and leave you guessing at the next twist. Just be sure that it will guide you very well onto the end. The game does have open world elements but the path is a little more restricted than I would like. There are a large number of areas but not every part of it is traversable. In Darksiders 2 , there are huge open fields and deserts which give a great feelign of the scale of the world. Darksiders feels kind of squashed into a small area. There is plenty of variety in your foes , though , so there probably won't be many times where you have to stop to look at the view.

Problem solving is in the game but is very minimal. Don't buy this if you are looking for puzzles from the old Tomb Raider games.

Length wise , the game is sufficiently long to keep you entertained. I would have liked a little more but perhaps it would run out of steam if it was going too long.

reviewText:
F***ING GREAT GAME!

it's like zelda, meets god of war, meets portal 1 and 2, meets some open world game.

visit this castle here, solve puzzles and find secrets areas which contain special items of sorts.... then go to that castle there and do the same.....fight the bosses. similar to zelda.

combat is like what you'd find in god of war...as is the scenery and background areas...and boss fights.

open a portal here, and one over there. go through one to come out the other. use this to get to certain areas unreachable. also use this to solve puzzles. similar to portal 1 and 2.

upgrade weapons and abilities, buy new comboes, and other upgrades, etc

game is pretty open, i wanna say it's open world.


PROS:
amazing graphics!
great story
upgrading system
battle system is great
visuals/scenery is cool looking
open worldish
secret areas with special items
boss fights
etc

CONS:
not a big fan of the puzzles at the end of the game...
towards the end of the game there isn't much action, but there are way to many puzzles and they are extremely difficult. i have beaten the game finally, if it werent for youtube walkthroughs i dont think id have been able to figure out acouple of these puzzles. thank god for youtube!! ;)

overall this is a great game, pretty balanced game play between the action combat and puzzles, very good story line, and fun to play.

reviewText:
With lengthy content, intense gameplay, apocalyptic setting, upgrade system, collectibles and some cool weapons Darksiders had a good potential to be an excellent game. However it just could not live up to my expectations. With cartoonish (yet crisp and clean) visual style, dull storyline and generic hack'n'slash experience it's just a mediocre game. Generally, there's nothing poor about it and yet nothing excellent either. It has just enough to keep you going until the end.

The only particular feature in this game I liked was the ability to summon and ride a horse (in the second half of the game). There are not many games you can do that.

However there were some faults in this game that allmost ruined the whole gameplay. They definitely were irritating.

- Slow ranged weapon controls.
- Gigantic bosses in small rooms. It does not substitute for good camera performance. When the developers will learn that? Atleast make the room bigger! So that the boss fits in the field of view.
- Overwhelmingly strong enemies at times, some of which are as strong as sub-bosses and it takes eternity to kill them.
- Bugs: achievements do not always unlock; some rooms do not unlock or freeze and you are forced to restart the whole game.
- Almost no clues. You have to guess everything on your own or watch YouTube to actually understand what to do.
- One of the last chapters is all about puzzles. It's a puzzle after a puzzle, after a puzzle, after a puzzle, some fighting and puzzles again. Not that the puzzles are hard, they're actually quite simple, it's just that this chapter is SOOO LOOOONG AND BORING, that I almost quit the whole game. It was a torment for me.
- Pointless game saving feature, because you will restart from the last checkpoint anyway (as with autosave), which would be fine unless....
- THE CUTSCENES! You enter the boss arena. A cutscene > 1 min, the boss kills you, you start from the checkpoint again. Each time you die, you are forced to watch the cutscene again. You can skip them, but not completely.

And, finally, what's with the anime locks hanging out from War's hood? Absolutely ridiculous!

What starts as a decent hack'n'slash experience ends as a torment. My overall rating 6/10.
Would I recommend to buy this game? Barely. Only with a discount.

Gaming level from Casual to Gamer.

Download contents DLCGlitches / bugs Yes, refer to (*) and (#).

- Review below ----------------------------------------------------------------------
This game remember me the Devil May Cry franchise, even if this one is less difficult than the devil may cry especially the ranking score which is missing. Unlike a Devil May Cry, you can explore an open world. The story is also as great as a Devil May Cry (DMC). As a DMC your currency are souls which are obtained by defeating ennemies or opening some chests. There are 3 kinds of souls in fact : health (green), currency (blue) and wrath (yellow). Like a DMC you'll unlock several close and long range fighting weapons, purchase many moves and wrath abilities. Finally there is the famous dungeons and bosses areas.

What a great game to feel strong and invincible. I would say a relaxing game.

(#) :
One very good glitch at the end of the game, is that you can spawn horsemen as you whish by leaving and entering the area. A very epic fight with your horse.

(*) :
If you wish to have all achievements you must follow the tips listed below (thanks to a guide on steam) :
- Turn off the steam overlay in the game, exit steam (steam -> exit), launch steam and play the game.
- You can only play one session of Darksiders in each steam session, if the game crash it count too. So the famous exit steam (steam -> exit), launch steam and play the game is needed.
- Always made saves before the part where you should unlock an achievement if you want to prevent the points above.

reviewText:
This is one of those games that is appealing on so many levels. For start, i immediately noticed that the game is designed beautifully, from world to creatures, and ofcourse, the main character which really looks like the embodyment of war, wielding the biggest, and the most badass sword since Buster Sword. Story is very well written and actors did an amazing job voicing those cut scenes followed by memorable soundtrack. As for the gameplay, being the most important aspect of video games in my oppinion, i would say that the developers nailed it.

I have heard people comparing Darksiders with Zelda games and i would say they are right, cause Darksiders is one of those multy gameplay aspect games. You will be doing everything from world exploring, treasure hunting, money farming, puzzle solving, character upgrading and battling all kinds of enemies in this game.

Exploration is fun and very enjoyable because of the above mentioned beutifully designed world and many secrets that it hides.  Often you will come across new tools that will allow you to revisit all those places you have been at before but now you would be able to reach all those previously inaccessible spots and claim their treasures.

Combat is great, and i loved the fact that every enemy is challenging in its own way and that you can easily get outnumbered and usually killed if you dont use all the tools and moves that are at your disposal. Its fairly simple but at the same time, requires concentration and awareness. You will want to learn your enemies moves and try to counter them when they make an opening or by executing a perfect parry which will usually devastate them. Sadly, this game has a reverse difficulty curve, meaning that it will be hardest at the start and in time, combat will become much less challenging as u grow in power. However, boss fights are amazing! They are a perfect blend of combat skills and puzzle, and you can always count on these to provide a fair challenge.

Also, you should know that this game is not very well ported for PC. Expect FPS drops in some areas(the Ashlands for me) and even game crashing, which, to be honest, happened to me only once, when i first ran the game and met Vulgrim. You probably wont be able to use controller unless u have original XBOX controller(my PS2 controller would make the game unplayable by fixing the camera at awkward angle simply by being plugged in), and no, x360ce probably wont work for you, so you are stuck with a keayboard and mouse. Another very annoying thing are steam achievements which you will not be able to get unless you are running the game for the first time. Every time you quit and re-run Darksiders, you wont be able to achieve anything. Luckily, this is fixed in seconds by simply quitting steam and re-starting it again but you will have to do it every time you wanna play this game.

I usually try to go in details with my reviews but, to be honest, that would be it. Game has a simple concept, A to B route, filled with battle encounters, secrets and occasional puzzles(which are also simple but fun), and its executed perfectly. If you take these bad PC porting flaws out of the picture, Darksiders is an amazing game and likely one that you will remember and recommend

reviewText:
In short, Darksiders is Legend of Zelda meets bloody apocalypse fighting. It's a fun game as the story was interesting with a decent enough hack and slash fighting system with combos and such. The enemies vary vastly and the bosses are always different. Big lack of PC settings though, you can only change the resolution and v-sync, no aliasing, filtering, etc, just poor port settings.

The gameplay, like I said, is similar in vein to The Legend of Zelda, but with a lot more blood. You are War, one of the Four Horsemen sent to confront Abaddon during the final Judgement on Earth. And you fight demons and sheeit, just like Link. The fighting style is even similar, block and attack when possible. Take advantage of enemy weak spots. Roll around and jump attack. Very similar indeed. Even the horse riding and climbing is similar.

Still a good game though, despite the flaws with the porting and some minor frame rate issues.

8.0/10

reviewText:
I loved parts of this game. The parts that were good were extremely good. The parts that were bad stuck out like a sore thumb. The story was amazing, characters were interesting, and the environment was ridiculously beautiful (as beautiful as a post apocolyptic world can be). This game had everything going for it. Weapon upgrades evenly spaced out giving you enough time to play around with them all without getting bored. I loved the sidequest that had me gather tokens from every zone, giving me rewards for each one i collected. This was the first game I used every single power up because they were ALL useful and beneficial. This is by far one of my personal favorite games I own.

Onto the bad. One thing that frustrated me most is that the Achievements for this game can and will glitch out. I cant even remember how many times i would find all the collectables and realize the game FORGOT to award the achievement and thus result in me having to RESTART THE GAME in order to get it all over again. This is only an issue if you care about achievements, this does not hinder gameplay in any way. The second thing I can complain about is the lack of replayability value to this game. Once you defeat the bosses and aquire the collectables, there is no reason to go back, and the enemies get replaced with weaker ones, making the zone a joke to clear. If this game let me restart with my currencies after i beat it, that would make it much more fun and give me that reason to play it again. But as it stands, once you obtain the collectables and beat the bosses, there isnt much of a reason to continue playing.

In conclusion, this game offered me a great experience while progressing through the story. Problems arose as you start entering your last quarter of the game where there becomes less and less to do. It's great that you aquired all 10 pieces of your abyssal armor set, to bad there isnt much to do in the game by the time you get it other than defeat the final boss with it or use it while obtaining the last few collectables.

8/10 if i were to rate this game. It's great but could've been better with just a few additions.

EDIT: apparently you can create a new game after you beat the last boss and start with the abyssal armor if you collected all the pieces in your first playthrough. This is vary nice and does add some replayability.

reviewText: With the brutality hallmarks of God of War, the dungeon layout, items and puzzle and world concepts of more recent Legend of Zeldas, and the dark and epic story that best recalls the weighty dialogue of the Legacy of Kain games, this game is something of an amalgamation.  And that's a good thing, because instead of simply taking those elements as they are (which is good enough as it is), this game takes all those elements and weaves them into an action adventure game where basically every moment is your character looking, sounding, and feeling like a badass.  In every detail, the position of the main character as a Horseman of the Apocalypse is never in question; your power is even evident in how the character walks and lands when jumping.  To be paired with this, the beautiful post apocalyptic world you explore is similarly fleshed out.  If you yearn for a solid, thorough action adventure game akin to the aforementioned games, this is more than worth a purchase.\n\nOne quick note, as an aside: there IS a quick way to amass souls once you finish the Ashlands.  YouTube would be the best place to look this up; it is heartily helpful for those that, like me, desire every powerup you can get in a game. ;)

reviewText: Darksiders is a typical example of what games were like before developers went crazy and started making every game open-world, have some form of multiplayer and flood the consumer with twelve DLC packs.\nIt's a return to the pre-2010 days, when linear action-adventure hack-and-slash games with a little bit of puzzle elements were the norm. This game is linear, but not in a bad way. It doesn't hold your hand at all times, and sometimes it leaves you having to figure things out on your own.\nThe combat system is not super deep, but it sure is entertaining to mow your way through dozens of enemies.

reviewText:
Darksiders was a welcome surprise when I tried it out a few years back. I’m a big fan of the game’s art design and concept, and the gameplay is deceptively simple despite looking really cool. You can watch the game’s opening cinematic on Youtube for a pretty good idea of what to expect in terms of story and style. It’s awesome.

First off, it’s an older title so most of you folks should be able to run it with no problem. The game is a 3d “hack & slash” played in third person perspective, but not “over the shoulder.” The game plays well with a controller, but I went through it with keyboard+mouse with no problems.  There’s no “loot” system so you’re fixed in the weapons you can use, but by unlocking different “moves” you can build combos. I’ve heard that the game is really similar to the God of War series in terms of combat, but I’ve never played those so I can’t say for sure. Not only is there a large variety in the enemies you can fight, but there are a bunch of boss battles too. Be warned though that there are puzzle elements to some of the levels which can get very annoying. I had to look online for puzzle solutions a few times.

In the story, you play as War, one of the mythical 4 Horsemen who are tasked with preserving “The Balance” between Heaven and Hell.  When the “End War” starts and Hell invades the Earth, it’s time for you to step in kick some ♥♥♥, both demon and angel. After you’re done with the game you might scratch your head a bit trying to figure out what happened (why did this character do that?) but when you’re actually playing it doesn’t pull you out of the game. Also, the ending cinematic really revs you up for the sequel.

Overall, the game a definite must play. It’s been in Humble bundles a few times so you might have it without even realizing it. It’s definitely worth your time to play through. A piece of advice though. If you’re playing the game for the first time with the help of an online walkthrough, DON’T collect the Abyssal armor for your first play through. It makes the game too easy.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A so called modern update to Link, The Legend of Zelda.  Darksiders is based on The Four Horseman of the Apocalypse though focuses on one, the protagonist War.

What his mission comprises I'll leave to your play-through but he is accompanied by a companion voiced by Mark Hamil of Luke Skywalker fame.  The voice acting is AAA Hollywood material and the characters really come to life because of it.

The combat is substantially solid and the weapons are few but are socket-able via modifiers and they level as well.  The move sets as usually found in this genre are purchasable by souls that you obtain through various methods.

Creative puzzles dominate some sections but may occasionally break the flow of the game.  There are the customary difficultly levels so whether you are an abecedarian or gods gift there's something here for everyone to luxuriate in.

The studio responsible for the production, Vigil Games were newcomers on the development scene when the game was produced but I was surprised to see in the credit roll that Silicon Knights had a hand in development as well.   A stellar production.

reviewText: We have a hopefully first out of four hack and slash games with a story so marvelous you'll be hooked up to your screens from the second you start the game until the end of it. I love the world design which has that special end of the world touch. It has every right to look that way since the story takes place in a time of war between angels and demons in which only the four horseman stand vast in the balance of the world. Story alone is worth every penny of this game. The main character of this game is War. The Badass horseman of the apocalypse which will be one of the most memorable characters you have ever played. The part I dislike about the game is the combat system. You have a massive amount of different combat moves from which you'll end up using only 2-3 in repeat. The other problem with combat system is that War is kind of slow. His moves are sluggish which give enemy a lot of space to break your attacks. Darksiders is a game you should have in your library thought it's a 7.5/10.

reviewText:
Darksiders is one of 2010's most underrated games in my opinion. The story is awesome (apocalypse, demons, angels and lots of destruction - what's not to like about that?) and the voice acting is just plain brilliant.

While you progress through the game you unlock new combat moves, weapons and abilities - such as the ability to summon Ruin, a fiery phantom steed which makes it easier and faster to travel through the certain areals of the world.

Every areal features new kinds of enemies such as angels, zombies, spiders, ghosts and more. The bosses are slightly more challenging as they are way faster, bigger and deadlier, which requires special tactics to beat them.

The playtime (depending on your personal playstyle) is around 8-12 hours for the story. If you want to max out all weapons, find all special abilities and collect all shadow armour pieces you can easily spend 30 hours with the game. I highly recommend playing the game with a Xbox360 controller to enjoy it at it's fullest!

reviewText:
Surprisingly difficult mix between platforming puzzle sovling and golden-axe-style hack'em and slash'em.
A god of war for the PC in many ways.  I recommend it for $5 sales or lower.

I did not enjoy the art style and graphics screamed console port, but this didn't take away from the experience too much, some probably prefer the oversized comic book styling of the characters.

The game's difficulty gets cranked up due to the array of tools needed to solve some of the level's puzzles - sometimes this made the game clunky and convoluted.  This certainly got tiresome when navigating the Black Throne and the constant repeat and repeat with slight mutations of the puzzles there within.

Except for the tediousness of the Black Throne, I found the puzzles to be a healthy mental challenge and found the bosses to be fun to figure out and defeat.  Tiamat in the beginning was very difficult.

I finished this game and missed only a handful of artifacts stashed throughout.
I maxed most of my abilities and tried everything in the game available to me.  I did not use Chaos form and Wrath enough for maxing out OP fun.  The most useful attack in the game is the dash sword attack, it works effectively against all of the enemies and deals the most damage.

I did run into a few known bugs, including:  some of saves were botched and I was forced to redo a couple of parts and a couple of play throughs didn't record achievments.

reviewText:
Wasn't expecting much when I first started playing it but man, I'm now glad I did! Its basically Zelda with a lot more mature setting and harder difficulty. You'll want to play on Apocalyptic difficulty or you'll be doing yourself a disservice!

The game strikes a good balance between combat, platforming and puzzles. I'll admit it, I was stumped a few times but with enough time and a careful eye you should be able to solve/spot the solutions to the games puzzles. The combat is combo based and requires some precision timing and dodging to do well. You also have various powers and 3 main weapon types that you can weave into the flow.

As for the setting its post-apocalyptic but ORIGINAL style, that is, ANGELS AND DEMONS and not nuclear war - I like angel/demon style better. :D Some truely epic sights to behold like a giant goth cathedral on an island surounded by lava, a giant desert with huge sand worms on the hunt and a truely massive demon tower looming in the background (your ultimate goal is to get into that tower). Its all connected via a HUB zone and you can freely travel back to previous areas to get goodies you may have missed like heart pieces (life shards) and bottles (vessels), haha its pretty Zelda-like but thats not a bad thing.

So, great game. Basically a mature, goth Zelda. Story isn't anything to write home about but it doesn't get in the way and the characters are all pretty awesome. 8.5/10

Games like Darksiders aren't Do whatever you want
date: build whatever you want" but they give you very specific tools that make interacting with the world fun.\n\nDarksiders was a satisfying game from beginning to end

hoursPlayed: then look no further than Darksiders."

reviewText:
Finished Darksiders on Oct. 11th 2014.

This game is fun. You play War, one of the four horsemen … to bring devastation on the world. And, oh my, you do. Hell is loose, the angels and daemons are fighting each other and in the middle is mankind. Well, mankind: not long.

Soon you find yourself tricked and are “accused” to have been showed up at the wrong time, since noone actually has called for you. You are brought before the cosmic council and you are given a second chance to remedy your “failure”. You are sent back to earth to only find out that centuries have passed since you have been trapped. You are weak and lost all your powers (and your horse). Further more, the council decided to attach an enervating spirit to you which watches every step you take. Step by step – level by level – you regain your powers and abilities back (and finally your horse too). You figure out who is behind your imprisonment and manage to take revenge. It’s a road movie in a post-apocalyptic world roamed by daemons and angels alike fighting each other … and you.

The action is pretty cool. You jump, swim, run, crawl, climb, etc. Fighting has some nice moves and as the game goes on you learn new skills and weapons. It really is smooth. The graphics are comic style nice and pretty to watch. The riddles range from easy to pretty awesome. And after learning new skills and abilities you tend to go back to levels you already cleared since you might now discover new places and spots you haven’t been before lacking the ability to fly to these places or even teleport (!). This game has looting features you get hooked on.

War is a cool character. … who is lost in a cool though confusing world.

The setting has some real nice touch. The world is filled with angels and daemons of all kind fighting each other and you’re fighting all of them. Some boss monsters are huge and some are pretty tough. Still one question remains: why I’m doing all this? What’s the point? The “mighty” council is a bundle of idiots easily fooled by a child or they deliberately sent War to prison … for what? Daemons and angels are fighting because … they don’t know what else to do? Yes, the overall action in the game is very addictive but the story could use some improvements. It seemed that some boy child fantasy has gone wild and just stopped at the point when one starts to justify all the action and reaction the characters in the game perform. “It’s there because … it’s just damn cool, isn’t it?”

Finally the controls: I played with my XBox controller on PC. First it starts all nice and easy. Pretty simple and clear. But as you learn new skills, abilities and weapons you find your controller overloaded with zillions of different moves and actions you can do. At the end I felt having about ~40 different key combinations to choose from. And as such I sometimes ended up jumping and flying around before I got the right keystroke to actually hit my foe. This is simply too much.

Still, a very pretty entertaining game.

7/10

reviewText: An often underlooked 3rd Person Action-Adventure game, with very satisfying combat, some open-worldy(ish) exploration and a gorgeous art style. Unfortunately this game also has one pretty major flaw/bug... Achievements. Or rather, they don't work properly. I HIGHLY recommend closing Steam entirely and re-opening it before launching this game (same goes for if you tab out) if you plan on getting every achievement in this game, or else many (for some unknown) reason may not unlock, forcing you to replay that section. It is also worth noting that I played this game with an Xbox 360 controller due to it's genre, and found the overall experience very enjoyable.\n\nWorth it, but not at full price.

reviewText:
Darksiders is a reasonably good game with a bad PC port.  I suggest getting it for a console.  The camera can be frustrating (and has caused some to rage quit), but the open world action and upgrade system is enjoyable if you can tolerate a bit of grinding for resources.

Don't expect this game to run well.  It will be choppy.  There will be no video settings other than resolution.  For most of my play, I had my old video card forced to display a smorgasbord of effects at 800x600.  I upgraded from a Radeon HD 3650 to a Radeon HD 7750.  The game was still choppy, but I upped the resolution and it ran just as well.

Do not play this game for achievements.  They often fail to register.  If they're really important to you, make sure to save right before so you can try again.  I didn't even get my endgame achievements.  Whats worse is that the game failed to register the armor I collected.  That really hurt because it was supposed to be available on my next playthrough.

Darksiders is another game that I ruined by grinding for things I don't need.  This is especially true since I didn't use anything other than a plot item in the final battle.  My weapons were fully maxed.  I finally gave up on my wrath abilities after maxing out two and getting the others one level shy.  I played in spurts over many months trying to complete chores that wouldn't even be registered for achievements.  All I had to do was warp to a location, ride my horse a bit and smack the end boss around.

Whatever my complaints, I'd take Ruin over Agro any day. ;)
