reviewText:
This is one of those games that you have to give a chance, cause you won't likely fall inlove with it immidiately. To my surprise though I liked this, more than the sequal.
Has many clever puzzles and enjoyable boss fights that each have their own gimmic to win. It's sort of like a gorey zelda clone.

The biggest issue I had with this game, was that I constantly felt under powered. The lowest level enemies take several hits to dispatch until the end. Didn't really find myself using anything more than 2-3 moves and the default sword  the entire game. Would really of liked to see more useful unique weapons as you progressed to replace it. There are other weapons, but their usefulness is debatable.

WARNING:
1) There seems to be a bug for some, where you have to restart steam everytime you play or you won't unlock achievements. So make sure you're unlocking them as you play.
2) Create an extra save right before collecting the final piece for abyssal armor. You'll need to load that save and recollect the final piece everytime you want to start a new game with the abyssal armor.

reviewText:
I almost passed on this game because I could not get it to run. Eventually following the troubleshooting guides, I did and I am very glad I took the time to do this.

Darksiders was a very solid action game. The gameplay is similar to God of War and the Batman Arkham series. While the textures and character may lack detail of other games, the action is fast, the framerates are extremely high, the voice acting is superb, and the story is decent.

The combat system is interesting, at first it seems if you mash the attack button (a controller is pretty much a requirement for Darksiders), you will kill everything is sight but this quickly becomes not the case. You need to be more careful, dodge, avoid, and counter. A full frontal assault rarely works. I do prefer the Batman Free Flow combat system though and it allows for endless combos a much more fluid experience.

To finish the game game you're looking around 13-15 hours, more if you plan on exploring every nook and cranny. I would go 8/10 for Darksiders.

reviewText:
Darksiders is one of 2010's most underrated games in my opinion. The story is awesome (apocalypse, demons, angels and lots of destruction - what's not to like about that?) and the voice acting is just plain brilliant.

While you progress through the game you unlock new combat moves, weapons and abilities - such as the ability to summon Ruin, a fiery phantom steed which makes it easier and faster to travel through the certain areals of the world.

Every areal features new kinds of enemies such as angels, zombies, spiders, ghosts and more. The bosses are slightly more challenging as they are way faster, bigger and deadlier, which requires special tactics to beat them.

The playtime (depending on your personal playstyle) is around 8-12 hours for the story. If you want to max out all weapons, find all special abilities and collect all shadow armour pieces you can easily spend 30 hours with the game. I highly recommend playing the game with a Xbox360 controller to enjoy it at it's fullest!

reviewText:
I had a lot of fun playing this game

First thing you notice when you jump into Darksiders is the cool, satisfying combat style the game has. War has a variety of moves, and the controls for the moves aren't very hard, but you still need to memorize them and be quick with your combos in order to beat some bosses and mini-games. The graphics are fine for a 2010 game, voice acting is well done, and the storyline is unique

Pros:
- Unique style of combat, love to execute big bosses and big monsters.
- Fun boss fights
- Solid graphics, could be better
- Good voice acting
- Some really cool environments

Cons:
- A lot of puzzles
- The game is quite linear, if you miss an important chest, you won't be able to get it at all.
- A couple random frame drop spots in the game.
- Regular price of the game is hefty for an outdated game

The good outweighs the bad in this game, I'd recommend you wait to buy it when it's on sale, because it goes on sale a lot, but if money isn't an issue for you, just pick it up and play

10/10 would behead demons again.

reviewText:
Darksiders seems like a safe bet.  Just take the overall game design of The Legend of Zelda, then give it a God of War combat system, and the art style from World of Warcraft.

Unfortunately, this paint-by-numbers approach misses the subtleties.  Zelda's charm, God of War's finesse, and Warcraft's humour are all notably absent, and this results in a game that suffers from a serious identity crisis.  It's really hard to take the games post-apocalyptic setting seriously when the visuals are just so... colourful.  It's hard to take the combat seriously when your combo library is so limited, upgrades and new attacks are so expensive, and your characters moves so slowly.  It's hard to find any charm when every character you meet is doing their best to be completely unlikeable.

The plot is stupid beyond belief.  You can tell that they're aiming to establish some deep and interesting lore here, but more often than not it just seems like they're making up the rules that govern the world as they go along.  I had trouble following certain elements, not because it was confusing, but because it was so uninteresting.  There are characters characters and concepts that are introduced in the early hours, but never revisited in the later game.

That's enough ripping on the game.  The truth of the matter is that Darksiders practically defines the 6/10.  Some good ideas, most of which are implemented well enough to make them seem interesting, but not enough to save the game from complete mediocrity.

The game's dungeons are truly Zelda-esque.  They manage good pacing between combat rooms and puzzle rooms, and the brainteasers manage to hit the sweet spot of 'not too easy, not too difficult' more often than not.  The one exception is the games final dungeon, which sees you scaling three massive towers with the help of a simplified 'Portal Gun'.  It's creative, but after clearing the first tower, it'll start to seem like pointless and tedious length-padding.  Oh, and each tower ends with the exact same mini-boss fight.  Not only that, but each of the paths towards the first two dungeons requires you to beat a series of combat challenges, some of which introduce some very immersion wrecking conditions.

The visuals are incredible.  In spite of it's grim-dark attitudes, the ruins of our civilization has some incredibly colourful locations.  Barren wastelands quickly give way to green vistas very early in the game, and the various locations each manage to maintain a different visual identity.  The levels are packed with plenty of detail, but it never gets in the way of communicating what you're supposed to interact with.

Overall, the game does deserve a qualified recommendation.  If you're genuinely curious to see what a mediocre Legend of Zelda game could look like, this is it.  Dull and repetitive combat, unlikeable characters, and a moronic plot bog down what was a generally enjoyable experience.  Darksiders is at it's best when your solving puzzles in any one of it's unique dungeons, and there's just enough of that to make the entire experience worthwhile...

reviewText:
Darksiders is wholeheartedly reminiscent of the Legend of Zelda series, all in a good way. For those who haven't played, these are your bog-standard action/adventure games with platforming puzzles, collection quests, a decent and interesting storyline, and lots of 3rd person hack and slash.

Darksiders manages to differentiate itself by composing an interesting and compelling universe loosely based on the Revelations chapter of the Bible. Even though humanity is long gone, the story has a strong moral binding and the characters are as dimensional as some of the best comic book characters.

There's plenty to do, see, collect, and fight - not to mention challenging traditional boss battles, beautiful artwork, and a storyline worthy of a novelization.

reviewText: An often underlooked 3rd Person Action-Adventure game, with very satisfying combat, some open-worldy(ish) exploration and a gorgeous art style. Unfortunately this game also has one pretty major flaw/bug... Achievements. Or rather, they don't work properly. I HIGHLY recommend closing Steam entirely and re-opening it before launching this game (same goes for if you tab out) if you plan on getting every achievement in this game, or else many (for some unknown) reason may not unlock, forcing you to replay that section. It is also worth noting that I played this game with an Xbox 360 controller due to it's genre, and found the overall experience very enjoyable.\n\nWorth it, but not at full price.

reviewText: The common concensus is that the 'next Zelda has come'. While I cannot agree with that, because honestly Darksiders just isn't that good, the game does come closer than any other before it. The art is fantastic and so are the voices. If anything, I'm more reminded of Soul Reaver than of Zelda. Darksiders is a solid game with rewarding combat and sensory delights. It can be repetitive and more than a little exhausting to play. And at times what it demands the player to do to progress can be excrutiatingly vague. Yet it is a rare duck and one worth playing, even if only for the purposes of demonstrating an endangered genre.

reviewText:
Darksiders is a great game.  You`ll play the apokalyptic horseman war on his campaign for revenge.
Now that sounds like an interesting plot, isnt it?
The Gameplay feels a lot like The Legend of Zelda, just with far more blood. You get an Advice, where to go, what to do, and who to kill, then you go on. But it wont get boring, some parts are challenging, some really easy. While playing, youll get more items, like the portal gun(ok, it has another name, but it is pretty much just like the portalgun). Some of those items will get you access to other areas, which motivates to revisit all the area (what you pretty much have to do, just before the endboss).

Darksiders has not the greatest textures, but it looks great with its comic-look. I recommend a gamepad to play this game, but Keyboard an Mouse work quiet good, too. The only negative point, that i have, is that youll run a lot more than fight, which can get annoying. And remember who holds the leash. :D

reviewText:
Darksiders is a reasonably good game with a bad PC port.  I suggest getting it for a console.  The camera can be frustrating (and has caused some to rage quit), but the open world action and upgrade system is enjoyable if you can tolerate a bit of grinding for resources.

Don't expect this game to run well.  It will be choppy.  There will be no video settings other than resolution.  For most of my play, I had my old video card forced to display a smorgasbord of effects at 800x600.  I upgraded from a Radeon HD 3650 to a Radeon HD 7750.  The game was still choppy, but I upped the resolution and it ran just as well.

Do not play this game for achievements.  They often fail to register.  If they're really important to you, make sure to save right before so you can try again.  I didn't even get my endgame achievements.  Whats worse is that the game failed to register the armor I collected.  That really hurt because it was supposed to be available on my next playthrough.

Darksiders is another game that I ruined by grinding for things I don't need.  This is especially true since I didn't use anything other than a plot item in the final battle.  My weapons were fully maxed.  I finally gave up on my wrath abilities after maxing out two and getting the others one level shy.  I played in spurts over many months trying to complete chores that wouldn't even be registered for achievements.  All I had to do was warp to a location, ride my horse a bit and smack the end boss around.

Whatever my complaints, I'd take Ruin over Agro any day. ;)

reviewText: They just don't make enough games like Darksiders anymore. Action platformers are sadly dying out in favor of twitch FPS's, moba's, and MMO's. Games with Darksiders perfect combination of satisfying hack and slash combat combined with varied and interesting environments are hard to come by.\n\nI miss the days of true adventure games like Ratchet & Clank, Jak & Daxter, Crash Bandicoot, Legend of Zelda, and other awesome exploration focused adventure games. Games like Darksiders aren't Do whatever you want
date: build whatever you want" but they give you very specific tools that make interacting with the world fun.\n\nDarksiders was a satisfying game from beginning to end
recommended: and if you want an awesome somewhat oldschool feeling adventure with a great story and artstyle
hoursPlayed: then look no further than Darksiders."

reviewText:
Finished Darksiders on Oct. 11th 2014.

This game is fun. You play War, one of the four horsemen … to bring devastation on the world. And, oh my, you do. Hell is loose, the angels and daemons are fighting each other and in the middle is mankind. Well, mankind: not long.

Soon you find yourself tricked and are “accused” to have been showed up at the wrong time, since noone actually has called for you. You are brought before the cosmic council and you are given a second chance to remedy your “failure”. You are sent back to earth to only find out that centuries have passed since you have been trapped. You are weak and lost all your powers (and your horse). Further more, the council decided to attach an enervating spirit to you which watches every step you take. Step by step – level by level – you regain your powers and abilities back (and finally your horse too). You figure out who is behind your imprisonment and manage to take revenge. It’s a road movie in a post-apocalyptic world roamed by daemons and angels alike fighting each other … and you.

The action is pretty cool. You jump, swim, run, crawl, climb, etc. Fighting has some nice moves and as the game goes on you learn new skills and weapons. It really is smooth. The graphics are comic style nice and pretty to watch. The riddles range from easy to pretty awesome. And after learning new skills and abilities you tend to go back to levels you already cleared since you might now discover new places and spots you haven’t been before lacking the ability to fly to these places or even teleport (!). This game has looting features you get hooked on.

War is a cool character. … who is lost in a cool though confusing world.

The setting has some real nice touch. The world is filled with angels and daemons of all kind fighting each other and you’re fighting all of them. Some boss monsters are huge and some are pretty tough. Still one question remains: why I’m doing all this? What’s the point? The “mighty” council is a bundle of idiots easily fooled by a child or they deliberately sent War to prison … for what? Daemons and angels are fighting because … they don’t know what else to do? Yes, the overall action in the game is very addictive but the story could use some improvements. It seemed that some boy child fantasy has gone wild and just stopped at the point when one starts to justify all the action and reaction the characters in the game perform. “It’s there because … it’s just damn cool, isn’t it?”

Finally the controls: I played with my XBox controller on PC. First it starts all nice and easy. Pretty simple and clear. But as you learn new skills, abilities and weapons you find your controller overloaded with zillions of different moves and actions you can do. At the end I felt having about ~40 different key combinations to choose from. And as such I sometimes ended up jumping and flying around before I got the right keystroke to actually hit my foe. This is simply too much.

Still, a very pretty entertaining game.

7/10

reviewText:
This is one of those games that you have to give a chance, cause you won't likely fall inlove with it immidiately. To my surprise though I liked this, more than the sequal.
Has many clever puzzles and enjoyable boss fights that each have their own gimmic to win. It's sort of like a gorey zelda clone.

The biggest issue I had with this game, was that I constantly felt under powered. The lowest level enemies take several hits to dispatch until the end. Didn't really find myself using anything more than 2-3 moves and the default sword  the entire game. Would really of liked to see more useful unique weapons as you progressed to replace it. There are other weapons, but their usefulness is debatable.

WARNING:
1) There seems to be a bug for some, where you have to restart steam everytime you play or you won't unlock achievements. So make sure you're unlocking them as you play.
2) Create an extra save right before collecting the final piece for abyssal armor. You'll need to load that save and recollect the final piece everytime you want to start a new game with the abyssal armor.

reviewText: Previous review was negative due to controller issues, as well as choppy cutscene/audio loss. I have resolved those issues. If you're experiencing the choppy cutscenes and audio loss and you have an NVIDIA graphics card, there is a solution. Use the nvidia control panel and find the options for vsync, make sure it's set to adaptive. Mine was set to allow the 3d application to choose. Darksiders doesn't choose for crap, so make the choice for it ;)\n\nGame is actually solid. Not incredibly original, but fun none the less. At 80% off right now, you can't go wrong. Get it.

reviewText:
I had a lot of fun playing this game

First thing you notice when you jump into Darksiders is the cool, satisfying combat style the game has. War has a variety of moves, and the controls for the moves aren't very hard, but you still need to memorize them and be quick with your combos in order to beat some bosses and mini-games. The graphics are fine for a 2010 game, voice acting is well done, and the storyline is unique

Pros:
- Unique style of combat, love to execute big bosses and big monsters.
- Fun boss fights
- Solid graphics, could be better
- Good voice acting
- Some really cool environments

Cons:
- A lot of puzzles
- The game is quite linear, if you miss an important chest, you won't be able to get it at all.
- A couple random frame drop spots in the game.
- Regular price of the game is hefty for an outdated game

The good outweighs the bad in this game, I'd recommend you wait to buy it when it's on sale, because it goes on sale a lot, but if money isn't an issue for you, just pick it up and play

10/10 would behead demons again.

reviewText: Darksiders is an interesting romp through various creation mythologies that were thrown into a blender and mixed to a perfect consistency. The story was one of the stronger aspects of the game, the combat being second. The platforming wasn't the greatest in various aspects, but it's sequel did improve on (still, screw those damn timed platforming sections because for the love of the monkey christ, you will not jump in the right direction without jumping at least 2-3 times to your death >_<.) The character and world design was absolutely fantastic, and I felt like I was running around in a Joe Madureia comic (he created Battle Chasers, his most well known work). The voice acting was pretty good, and while I love Mark Hamill to absolute death......The Watcher sounded like a constipated Joker. I don't think it was entirely Mark's fault, for all we know, the VO director could have just told him Do a pissy Joker and let's call it a day" and that's what he did. Other than a few hiccups in the VO's where the emotion wasn't really being sold (sometimes in dramatic times they almost sounded bored)
date:
but that was few and far between. I will conclude with scores below (cause who doesn't like obligitory score systems?)

Combat: 8/10
Character and World Design: 9/10
Platforming: 6.5/10
Story: 9.5/10
Replayability: 6/10

Overall: 8/10

This game was well done effort that deserves your time."

reviewText: This is a zelda-type action RPG. You play as the second horseman of the apocalypse, War, who handles basically like you'd hope a space marine would (I'm looking at YOU, other THQ property). War has as many moves as you'd hope from a Devil May Cry or a Bayonetta. The fighting is fun, the platforming is decent, and the puzzles bog down real hard near the end, which hurts the pacing. The plot is silly. You should buy this game if you don't already own it as part of a bundle pack.\n\nRIP THQ

reviewText:
The best Zelda game that I've played.

It's essentially a mix of Zelda-like progression with a bunch of hidden useful collectables that get accessible when you unlock more gear and a flashy heavy-feeling DMC-lite combat with somewhat gruesome finishing moves that you can perform on mobs. The combat is somewhat repetitive owing to a limited number of weapons (just 3 melee weapons) and general uselessness of ranged weapons outside of solving puzzles, but is held up by how awesome it feels.

Plently of hidden collectibles that almost directly impact your health and mana capacity, weapons can be upgraded by the means of combat, and additonal moves and upgrades can be bought from an in-game merchant.

In short, the best Zelda game that I've played, and I wholeheartedly recommend it. Because it's good.

reviewText: I usually don't play this type of games, but thought I'd try to play something different for a change. Maybe that's also the reason why I liked it so much. This game got me captivated from the first seconds, thanks to the constant epicness of the the game universe. The gameplay is also breeze. There are large number of different moves the player could make, which looked a bit intimidating at first, but in the end a set of few moves is enough to get through most fights (at least in normal difficulty). All boss fights were manageable after a few tries.\n\nYes, there were also plenty of downsides. The console port is of quite poor quality. The keyboard+mouse controls work well, but the keybindings are a bit strange at first. The game crashed quite a few times and also features a very annoying bug where steam achievements are not registered unless you restart steam before playing the game. Running around the map also got boring towards the end. Still, you can live with these and the game is definitely worth playing.

reviewText: An often underlooked 3rd Person Action-Adventure game, with very satisfying combat, some open-worldy(ish) exploration and a gorgeous art style. Unfortunately this game also has one pretty major flaw/bug... Achievements. Or rather, they don't work properly. I HIGHLY recommend closing Steam entirely and re-opening it before launching this game (same goes for if you tab out) if you plan on getting every achievement in this game, or else many (for some unknown) reason may not unlock, forcing you to replay that section. It is also worth noting that I played this game with an Xbox 360 controller due to it's genre, and found the overall experience very enjoyable.\n\nWorth it, but not at full price.

reviewText:
Darksiders is a reasonably good game with a bad PC port.  I suggest getting it for a console.  The camera can be frustrating (and has caused some to rage quit), but the open world action and upgrade system is enjoyable if you can tolerate a bit of grinding for resources.

Don't expect this game to run well.  It will be choppy.  There will be no video settings other than resolution.  For most of my play, I had my old video card forced to display a smorgasbord of effects at 800x600.  I upgraded from a Radeon HD 3650 to a Radeon HD 7750.  The game was still choppy, but I upped the resolution and it ran just as well.

Do not play this game for achievements.  They often fail to register.  If they're really important to you, make sure to save right before so you can try again.  I didn't even get my endgame achievements.  Whats worse is that the game failed to register the armor I collected.  That really hurt because it was supposed to be available on my next playthrough.

Darksiders is another game that I ruined by grinding for things I don't need.  This is especially true since I didn't use anything other than a plot item in the final battle.  My weapons were fully maxed.  I finally gave up on my wrath abilities after maxing out two and getting the others one level shy.  I played in spurts over many months trying to complete chores that wouldn't even be registered for achievements.  All I had to do was warp to a location, ride my horse a bit and smack the end boss around.

Whatever my complaints, I'd take Ruin over Agro any day. ;)

reviewText: It's got a generic story with various blatantly borrowed influences from classics such as Zelda, God of War and Portal (?!). Aside from these flaws, the game sports a fairly impressive and responsive combat system which makes taking down hordes of enemies a gore-tacular breeze, although it does become repetitive. The level design is great however, favouring a dungeon-like free-roaming hybrid over that of conventional level systems, arguably to its own benefit. The in-game collectibles are challenging to complete and offer incentives to explore, offering a reason to diverge from the story path. The voice acting is rubbish, the story predictable and the soundtrack painfully generic, although this really is a fun, long-lasting experience, eased by an expansive weapons and combo system and a lovably gothic art direction with excellent graphics. Oh and the boss battles are welcomely grand.\n\n7/10

reviewText:
If you are a Zelda Fan, this is the game for you. Pretty much identical to a Zelda game: Dungeons, Hearts and Containers, Souls (Rupees), and most importantly IMO the concept of using items you get in dungeons to advance through the game and kill the bosses. There's also an element of Portal later in the game as well, so if you like Portal then that is a plus.

My one main criticism is the storyline. There are 5 dungeons, and the vast majority of them involve getting the hearts of the chosen - the story really takes place during the beginning and end of the game aside from meeting Ulthane. Also, I'll mention some items are MISSABLE - particularly all items in the final dungeon.

If you like Zelda, you'll like Darksiders. If you love Zelda, you'll love Zelda. Get this game if you haven't. Now. It's a 9/ 10.

reviewText: Previous review was negative due to controller issues, as well as choppy cutscene/audio loss. I have resolved those issues. If you're experiencing the choppy cutscenes and audio loss and you have an NVIDIA graphics card, there is a solution. Darksiders doesn't choose for crap, so make the choice for it ;)\n\nGame is actually solid. Not incredibly original, but fun none the less. At 80% off right now, you can't go wrong. Get it.

reviewText: I usually don't play this type of games, but thought I'd try to play something different for a change. Maybe that's also the reason why I liked it so much. This game got me captivated from the first seconds, thanks to the constant epicness of the the game universe. The gameplay is also breeze. There are large number of different moves the player could make, which looked a bit intimidating at first, but in the end a set of few moves is enough to get through most fights (at least in normal difficulty). All boss fights were manageable after a few tries.\n\nYes, there were also plenty of downsides. The console port is of quite poor quality. The keyboard+mouse controls work well, but the keybindings are a bit strange at first. The game crashed quite a few times and also features a very annoying bug where steam achievements are not registered unless you restart steam before playing the game. Running around the map also got boring towards the end. Still, you can live with these and the game is definitely worth playing.

reviewText:
In apocalyptic, biblical literature, Armageddon is usually associated with the end of life on Earth, and is represented in popular media by extreme, blockbuster scenarios. For Vigil Games' interpretation, the dogmatic themes of the source material are disassociated from the event, but familiar characters persist in their debut title, Darksiders. In Vigil's canon, the End of Days may be a catastrophic struggle between heaven and hell, but for War, one of the Horsemen of Apocalypse, it's really just a dastardly prank call.

As I already mentioned, Darksiders has you taking the role of War, one of the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse. In the early stages of the game, War comes out of the underworld to find the Apocalypse has taken place before it should have and mankind has been destroyed. Due to this rather monumental mistake, War has been stripped of his former power, as he is the prime suspect.

War escapes with his life due to his bargaining abilities, and his desire to discover the true cause. He's tasked with the intention of annihilating the Destroyer, who is the ruler of Hell, by The Charred Council, which are a kind of group which attempts to mediate in the war between heaven and hell. They also chain War to the Watcher, a demon that has the power to kill War if he sets a foot wrong. Fortunately for the player, the Watcher actually acts as an indication of where to go at times, or what objectives to complete, rather than simply destroying War for tripping over a ledge.

The game focuses largely on gameplay mechanics that have been tried and proven in other franchises. Zelda is a big influence here, and the way you collect pieces to level your character, as well as the at-times puzzle-heavy gameplay harks back to this. It's by no means bad, as the setting and characters are so vastly different. Another very big influence is God of War, and it certainly seems that while gamers wait until God of War 3 is released, Darksiders makes for an incredibly close experience. The controls and attacks could all be ripped directly from God of War, particularly the ability to do finishing moves on all enemies once dazed.

On top of this, orbs are collected firstly as currency, secondly as life-force, and thirdly as a form of mana allowing you to perform special magical attacks. This works extremely well though, and in some ways it feels like a large improvement on God of War, particularly in that there is less button-mashing and much more in the way of fluid attacks and movement. The balance has been struck extremely well between the puzzle and platforming action genres, and it is refreshing that exploration and puzzles take precedence over combat. They do say that imitation is the sincerest form of flattery.

Combat is still a very important part of the game. Ripping the heads off demons clearly is something that we can all enjoy, and Darksiders makes it difficult not to. The stunning gore effects and the fast-paced action and combo attacks are implemented wonderfully, making them for the most part easy to engage. It's made more interesting by the wonderful character models and character animations. The models are all done in an exaggerated comic book style. Enormous swords, giant armour plating, out of this world weaponry and of course dark, brooding environments.

The graphic style works very well to bring the apocalypse to our living rooms by making blood spray, and the action is highly stylised and totally befitting of the character models - in particular the giant swords. The graphics themselves look fantastic and it would be hard to wish for anything more at this stage. The movements are fluid and the attacks hit home hard. As you upgrade your weapons and find more you gain access to an additional range of combo attacks that make for even more spectacular gameplay.

The range of weapons and items in Darksiders helps to prevent things from becoming same-old" too fast. As you roam the open-world landscape on foot or on your trusty steed you will come across item modifications which can be attached to your various weapons. These give a range of effects that will significantly help you fight your way to the deepest corner of Hell
date: and also allow you to customise the gameplay experience to an extent. War can always choose between a secondary and a primary weapon
recommended: both of which he can attack with at any given time.\n\nOn top of this War has access to magical attacks which he can engage provided he has enough mana souls. These are generally powerful and particularly helpful when in a bind

reviewText:
I'm perhaps the most pathetic Zelda fan you'll ever see.  I've played one game, Ocarina of Time on Wii's virtual console, and yet I dare to call myself a fan.

Fanboy, faker, whatever you say, I've been looking for good Zelda-esque games for a long time.  While Metroid and Dark Souls were certainly good (Metroid Prime especially), a game faithful to the Zelda style of gameplay hasn't appeared for me yet.  And, now I'm here.

Darksiders is great.  I haven't played much of it yet, but as soon as I knew what it was, I instantly knew I had to get it.  Family Sharing wasn't working in this case for some reason (I haven't heard complaints about this, so I'll go ahead and say it was a rare case and you should be fine), but I saw this on sale with Deathinitive Edition and took the plunge.

I can already tell I'm not going to refund this one.  Down to the Z Targeting and dodge mechanic, this game nails the Zelda style of combat and gameplay and from what I can tell, it even uses a semi-open world of derelict New York.  Not to mention, it throws in God of War's combat-masher style of gameplay and surprisingly it mixes well with Zelda's very dodge-roll based and item-friendly systems of gameplay.

While this may not be a review as much of a first impressions, I have to say that it's really great so far.  Now, continue to mock me for forgetting about Twilight Princess; I deserve your mockery.

Oh, and one quick warning: the port isn't great.  Very limited options and obviously meant for a controller.  However, performance is acceptable (aside from some pretty bad stuttering) on my own system, and the stuttering problems disappear for some reason when using Big Picture mode for Steam.  You've been warned, get out your Xbox 360 pad and use Big Picture if you actually want to have some fun here.

reviewText:
What about Darsiders? : Darsiders is an Action Adventure Fantasy with a pinch of RPG but mainly Hack&Slash game.
You are WAR, one of the 4 Horsemen of the Apocalypse and you have answered the call of the 7 seals bringing Chaos and Destruction on Earth. But something isn't right, it seems that you have been deceived by the Forces of Evil becasue the 7Seals are still intact. Brought to the Council, you have been accused of breaking the Truce between Hell and Heaven and started the War which see the Destruction of Earth. Stripped off your Powers, you are send back to Earth to uncover the truth and those responsible the treachery and seek Revenge.
The plot as you can see is interresting and keep you going as you can't wait to find out who's behind all this, the graphics are really good and most of all even if it was a console port, the Devs have made an effort to optimise Keyboards and Mouse users, and i really appreciate that.
The character is well designed, the attacks options and variety of moves make the game quit enjoyable, some very nice cutscenes to keep you hook up and also huge end Bosses to test your skills.
There are also some RPG ingredients and you can upgrade your character with more powerfull gears and items, souls of your victims are used as currency so the more you kill the richer you get yeah that's evil :D.
Overall Darsiders is a great Action game, well worth getting specialy right now when Steam Summer Sales is on, you will not regret it, i clearly didn't.

reviewText: The best way I can describe the Darksider series is an interactive book.  The lore is so creative and so good, the driving force for me to push into the game was to findout what was going to happen.  The story line was that good for me.  The overall gameplay I enjoyed, however there is one complaint.  It basically happens in the last dungeon, but the pace of the game drastically changes.  There are puzzles throughout the game, but the last dungeon got pretty rediculous quick.  I guess I am dumb, but I had to go to walkthroughs to finish the last dungeon.  The pace of the game drastically slowed down.  The fighting is somewhat challenging, but I personally didn't need all the various combos at your disposal.  I stuck with the very basics, and was able to beat the game just fine.  Which totally negates the point of having those.\n\nIn retrospect, they could of done things differently to make the game even better, but I will say the game as it is is very worth it.  The cliffhanger at the end of the game is just so cool.  And it sets you up for the second Darksiders, and makes you eager to play the next game in the series.

reviewText:
The most tryhard hero ever (can't even speek a word without trying to speak extra grim while giving the impression he is getting tortured right at that moment) in a very unimaginative story (apocalypse, demons and stuff) goes on an endless quest to fetch stuff for some demon or something. He can also fetch other stuff.

I mean, i can understand this game is not about story, but it all feels like a careless hull for the actual heart of the game: The Combat. Unfortunately the combat is not that good. After having played games like Dark Souls and DMC 3/4/Reboot, the combat is just a lot worse than all of those and just does not feel exciting imo.
The enemies patterns are very easy to learn and once learned you just grind down the health of the bigger enemies / bosses (the smaller enemies can be pretty much ignored.) An exception are the angels (in groups), which are actually interesting to fight because of their ranged attacks, but that does not make up for the rest. Hit-n-Run tactic almost always works.
The manual aim mode is too slow to be effective in combat most of the time. The weapon update system is very simplistic and once you have found your favorite weapon upgrade, thats it (you can only mount one update per weapon, though you can switch between 2 weapons and you have an offhand ability which can also be upgraded).

There are puzzles and platform elements, though neither are challenging in any way. Instead of few bigger puzzles (which i would have preffered) there are a lot of small push-that-button or push-that-box-to-climb-up or light-that-torches-to-blow-up-things type puzzles, they arent too bad i guess. The hero can climb and swim really fast, which i REALLY liked. So points for this stuff.

When it comes to graphics (which of course are outdated by now), the overall art style fits together nicely. There is only one problem: The hero. His running looks bad. He runs like a poorly animated dwarf. This adds in making his tryhard character appear quite rediculous and out of place. Bonus points in design for these big living Rock-Portal-Blockers though. Sound is okay.

TLDR:
Mediocre gamplay. The hero's way of taking anything WAY too seriously with his characteristics of an angry stone drains away a lot of the atmosphere the world could have spread and does spread in rare moments.

reviewText:
19-Apr-2016 : Finished main story + extras
Equipment : MSI GT80-2QE Notebook

REVIEW :
Graphics are a bit outdated since we're talking about 6 year old game here, but I think it is pretty good compared to other 2010 games. The gameplay took the best part of Soul Reaver, Devil May Cry and Portal. The story and characters are unique with good voice acting and soundtracks.The story ends with a cliffhanger and I can't wait to play as the other three horsemen. It took me 19 hours to complete it on the highest difficulty setting and I didn't even feel it, time just flies. This should be a sign of a good (if not great) game.

CONCLUSION :
Recommended on full price, a must-have on sale price.

PS :
* To unlock Steam Achievements properly, always restart Steam before running Darksiders.
* To unlock the Xbox/PS3 pre-order bonus, The Harvester Scythe, hex edit the save file.

reviewText: This was a fantastic hack and slash dungeon crawler that I enjoyed immensly. There are tons of secrets and upgrades to find with areas you have to revisit later on to get access to previously unreachable sections if you want to collect everything. The combat is brutal and bloody and the boss fights reminded me of Zelda games, challenging yet fair boss fights where you have to find each boss's weakness. Overall if you like action games I recommend picking this one up even at the full price. It does go on sale every couple of months if you are the patient type so your call!

reviewText: An original IP that is based on the 4 horesemen of the apocalypse. Similar to the Zelda franchise: you explore dungeons while acquiring weaponry and items that help in reaching otherwise unreachable areas and equipment that helps in various ways from powering up to revealing hidden chests on the map. If you like the Zelda franchise, this is pretty much up your aisle. The only downside is that there are only 5 dungeons, although the last one is so damn long it might as well count as two. But for 20 dollars, the price justifies the length and originality in the IP. It should take around 20 hours to complete; so a dollar an hour. More bang for your buck than going to the movies.

reviewText:
I have over 500 games in my Steam account, and the vast majority of them are still unplayed. So now I'm dedicating an hour to each of these games and writing a series of One Hour Reviews. An hour isn't very long to judge a game on, so think of this as more of a first impression, and take this review in the spirit in which it's given. Be sure to read other reviews from players who have spent more time in the game.

One Hour Reviews #40 - Darksiders

My first reaction to Darksiders as I played it was that it was very reminiscent of God of War.  I don't consider that a bad thing, but it's hard not to make the comparison as you are hacking and slashing through demons.  But I think it would be a disservice to simply call this a God of War clone, as there are some differences that make Darksiders stand on its own, particularly with it's emphasis on puzzles.

The art style has a comic book influence to it, and I thought it worked well.  The only negative is a relative lack of graphic options.  You can change resolutions and set v-sync, but otherwise there are no real customization options.  This isn't a dealbreaker to me at all, and I would still recommend this game.  I'm definitely looking forward to spending more time in it.

The Bad: Not enough itemization or character depth.
The Ugly: Unclear objectives in puzzles, unclear waypoints to progress. Extremely ambiguous expected ways of killing certain bosses which turn into feedfests till you figure it out. Tedious mid-late end game.

reviewText: The worst you can say about Darksiders is that there's hardly an original bone in its body. The game is broadly a mix of God of War and Zelda, even down to the same structure of dungeons, chests, keys and a horse, but it doesn't reach the high standards of the games it copies, and the art style and tone of the game aren't particularly inspiring either.\nHowever, it is solidly-made and usually fun. There are some frustrating bits (one in particularly where I nearly threw in the towel) but if you can forgive the unoriginality and you get on with repetitive enemy encounters, you'll probably find something to enjoy. I found it okay, but I wouldn't particularly recommend it.

reviewText: If you love Zelda like I do there isn't really much choice if you want a similar game on the PC. So you're stuck with Darksiders really. It's pretty good, the graphics are decent (I still have a feeling it lacks something, I don't know why) and the dungeons are pretty cool and cleverly made. One thing I didn't really enjoy was the God Of War-like combat. There are just too many fights (I don't mind bossfights obviously) and it just felt like button mashing all the time. What I'd rather see is an 'open' world where you can explore things, yes, just like Zelda. So, for Darksiders 2: less combat, more exploring. Give us that and it will be a brilliant game ! This is a good start nonetheless, give it a try.\n\n[Rating: 86/100]

reviewText:
After playing this game on the PS3 I have to admit it's a very good role playing/action adventure game the combat is good and can be frustrating at times but the game offers a good variety and to me doesn't get boring, the story is about the end of days and the HELL war between heaven and Hell. The seals that prevent this war have somehow been broken and thus the END WAR begins with that happening the 4 horseman of the apocalypse are summoned to end this war but not all is as it seems with only 1 horseman been summoned WAR. As you progress you learn that the charred council who are the order that brings balance are not happy and accuse WAR of causing the mayhem that has become and thus take his powers away from him that they once gave. They give him a chance to redeem himself under close guard or a guardian of the council who keeps a close watch over WAR and makes sure he does what is necessary  in order to put things right.

The story is very good and sometimes it can be a little confusing but it does well to get you back on track with the plot game play wise there are a few announces like the main map for instance it's based on the old floor style system where you bring it up and move it layer upon layer to see the floors of the area(s) should there be any. This can be annoying when finding items for some and trying to find out where to go next as there is no marker to show you the right direction, the game even on easy can be a challenge if you don't master the block system it's a timed move to slow down and get in a quick attack but when facing a lot it can be a challenge to defend against them to keep your health up. The difficulty even on easy is reversed in a way as you progress and find items to expand your health and fight for souls to upgrade weapons via EXP it gets easier but it does make it challenging with the boss fights.

I had a lot of fun playing this on PS3 and the PC version runs faster with the better frame rate which make it even better to play but I would seriously recommend playing this on PC or consoles because it's worth it, but for PC users I do recommend also you use a Microsoft wired 360 controller for less hassle, I just purchased Darksiders 2 on PC as well as this and I can't wait to play it as the next horseman that is DEATH. I really do hope that they finish off the franchise with the other 2 horseman that is FURY and STRIFE

reviewText: It's easy to draw parallels between Darksiders and the The Legend of Zelda series, it would be no surprise if the developers at Vigil Games created Darksiders as an homage of sorts, especially to Ocarina of Time. Here you have a doppelganger to a basic run-of-the-mill puzzle platformer that we've come to expect from Nintendo: levels with an emphasis on the elements, particularly lava, water, earth, desert, dark, and light, where the only way to complete each level is through a set of challenging obstacles and various enemies, not to mention the cliché third time's the charm" when it comes to boss fights.\n\nDarksiders is a pretty solid game
date: it has its moments and it has its downfalls but its major defining element is its ability to deliver a well-paced experience with little tedium and monotony
recommended: as items that you collect along your journey are spread out enough to feel quite rewarding with an urge to instantly try out your new shiny device
hoursPlayed: sending you onto the next level only to stumble across another shiny device
voteText: ad infinitum. The enemies are also varied enough
helpfulPercent: and many are unique to their levels
votesHelpful: which keeps things interesting.\n\nThere is a small amount of backtracking
votesTotal: which is heavily expanded on if you wish to collect every item in the game as there is a large incentive to do so. The levels are all well designed and can easily be returned to due to the prevention of the dreaded "point of no return" that many JRPG fans would be familiar with.\n\nFor me
votesFunny: the highlight of the game was the dialogue
commentsCount: simply because Mark Hamill is such a superb voice actor
column16: as proven by his long standing career as the voice of The Joker. The sound design is pretty wicked and everything sounds as you would expect: ethereal and apocalyptic.\n\nThe only disadvantages to Darksiders are the myriad of technical issues I had
column17: whether they be glitches with the game's mechanics or bugs preventing certain situations from progressing. One achievement failed to unlock when it was supposed to
column18: and the game crashed no less than four times in one sitting. Twice
column19: due to alt-tabbing and another two times simply because the game bugged out. There are very limited graphical options
column20: sorely missing is a FoV slider as the default FoV is somewhat smothering and isn't suitable for PC standards.\n\nAnother personal parallel I can draw between this game and The Legend of Zelda is the drastic length of time it took to beat the campaign. I started playing Darksiders in September of 2011
column21: finishing it in February of 2013. Similar to Ocarina of Time
column22: where I decided to take a several year long break due to

reviewText: If you love Zelda like I do there isn't really much choice if you want a similar game on the PC. So you're stuck with Darksiders really. It's pretty good, the graphics are decent (I still have a feeling it lacks something, I don't know why) and the dungeons are pretty cool and cleverly made. One thing I didn't really enjoy was the God Of War-like combat. There are just too many fights (I don't mind bossfights obviously) and it just felt like button mashing all the time. What I'd rather see is an 'open' world where you can explore things, yes, just like Zelda. So, for Darksiders 2: less combat, more exploring. Give us that and it will be a brilliant game ! This is a good start nonetheless, give it a try.\n\n[Rating: 86/100]

reviewText:
I will consider various sides of this game, trying to be the more objective as possible.
These sides are:
♦ The Gameplay
♦ The Graphics
♦ The Lore

Let's ride!
♦ The Gameplay
This is probably the most boring game I've ever played.
It's a classic Action/HnS like God of War, but unlike the Sony's pillar this game is repetitive and predictable.
There are very little combos, made only with the main attack button and the move control.
There are tons of enemies, but the vast majority are just retexture of previous encounters with higher stats or in larger groups.
The only difficulty is that in some parts of the game there are a few of overpowered enemies that only make the game more frustrating without adding any true challenge.
The platform/puzzle sections are nice since you don't have any suggestion and you just have to find the way by yourself.

♦ The Graphics
This is very controversial.
The texture of the characters are beautiful and ashtonishing, but the same can't be said for the enviroment and for the models: the ground looks gross and the models are too pointy. Even how the texture are placed is horrible.
The game overall looks like an HD remake of a PSX game.

♦ The Lore
This is the only point where i can't find a leak.
It's awesome.
A tittle too slow thanks to the gameplay, but it's how games should be played.


DarkSiders in a nutshell:
((-Slay tons of enemies
-Drag stuff around
-Slay more enemies
-Destroy stuff
-Slay a miniboss) Repeat x10
-Slay enemies
-Kill a Boss) Repeat x10


I can't suggest you to buy this game for full price, but if you like the genre very much and/or it's on sale, buy it!
6/10

reviewText:
Well this was fun to play if you are into the hack and slash style of playing. I reminded me of the Castlevania Lord of Shadows kind of fun. Once you get used to your controls, the game is pretty good. Though you may have to resort to watching YouTube video on walkthroughs and how to deal with certain situations, it's not always obvious on what you have to do like fighting Tiamat. It's not a boring game to play since you have to go through many different places, like the desert, the water, underground sturctures, lava pits, etc... the different environments and different bosses you fight keeps things interesting.

The only downside I saw is that a few achievements that should have been unlocked, did not unlock. Could be a bug, but it doesn't affect game play. So it's up to you on how annoyed you would get by not getting an achievement you are supposed to get. Perhaps when I try on the second time around, it will unlock.

I quite enjoyed it myself that I went and bought Darksiders 2. I will be playing Darksiders again in the future it was that good for me.

reviewText:
EDIT:As of now after encountering all these obstacles and finally being able to play again I feel I'll redo this review slightly while I still dislike the gameplay and technical state this port is in. I will say this game still has been very fun and sorry if I didn't make that as clear in the original, this game was running the meh opinion and with only 2 options it was hard to pick but will the frustration with some of the technical issues I chose the latter. However I'll revise and give it a recommend because I was able to actually continue on and finish it.



This will be the first game I don't recommend and for good reason. While the game itself is enjoyable and awesome (makes the cons even worse really) is the fact that the game is not very stable or reliable and Im referring to gameplay stability rather than actually running the game. There are some bugs which can screw you over here and there but while playing I brushed them off, however the straw that broke the camel's back was the irreversible literal game breaking puzzle bugs. I made it as far as turning in the four hearts and was backtracking for collectibles/armor/shards etc. While doing so my character is now forever locked in the Hollows because of the train puzzle. Ther is no physical way of me leaving the dungeon now and I really didnt feel like giving up another 10hrs of my playtime to just finish the things the game had broke for me. 5/10 phenominal game, terrible pc port

reviewText:
God of War + Legend of Zelda + Portal.

Extremely repetitive combat, this game should take notes from the Batman Arkham series.  A mildly interesting story.  I stopped hating it after about 8 hours and actually started to like it at 15-20 hours.  But man, it's hard to recommend even for $5.  It has a lot of faults.  Its just a brainless semi-linear/semi-open world 3rd person brawler/fighter/action platformer kind of game.  Also, the game bugs out & crashes a lot.

Overall, its about a 6/10 or a 5/10, barely worth $5.

reviewText: Sure, Darksiders took a lot from the Zelda games, but DmC Devil May Cry took a lot from this game: gliding on angel wings, press V for Super mode, using powers in puzzles, killing enemies turns them into skulls which function as currency, buying little consumables in stores using skull money, ALL the moves with the Scythe and Fist weapons.  It's a good formula.\n\nAlthough it's 2009 release date and shoddy port still shows--there are no graphics options other than resolution and V-sync--it's still a pretty good open world RPG. The combat is great, the pacing is not great (think Assassin's Creed I). If it goes on sale, I'd say pick it up.

reviewText: Worst port for a game I've ever come across, bar none.  If you're one of the few people lucky enough to get a copy that doesn't require a 3rd party controller emulator, then you should pride yourself on falling into a rare demographic.  Aside from the countless UI indescrepancies and complete lack of keyboard support, the game also suffers from many bugs, many of which are gamebreaking in nature.  If you are honestly thinking of making this purchase on steam, head over to the community hub, and check out the many posts about bugs and scenerios where the game simply doesn't work.  If you wanna play, but it for console.  This game is in desperate need of a patch that will never come.  Do not buy it on Steam.

reviewText:
While Darksiders satisfied my twitchy thumbs to a certain degree when it came to button-mashing combat, I grew tired quickly of the apocalyptic environments and simple switch/key platforming puzzles. For something with such a dark theme, the game was too cartoony and colourful for me, with its rainbow demons and showers of particle effects. Every area seemed to be lit from within, with no shadows in sight.

Perhaps the worst problem was the clunky controls for aiming thrown objects, using my Xbox gamepad. Combined with a unhelpful camera, it made ranged combat sections of the game more frustrating than fun.

I think my teenage self might have loved this game, but the adult me wanted something a bit more straightforward, with a better told story.
voteText: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Who is this Game For?
==================
People that relate this game to Zelda have no idea what they are talking about. If I was to make a comparison, the closest game Darksiders resembles is Force Unleashed II. There is not one puzzle in this whole game as far as I could tell in my play through. The game always told you exactly what to do, and if there was something that could be a puzzle in a room, the auto-camera makes sure to zoom onto objects and paths that need to be explored, eliminating any thought process that might otherwise be needed. It’s a straight up hack-n-slash. If that's what you are into, get this title.

Is it good?
=================
The boring linear gameplay, and almost no character progression, does not exactly have a recipe for a winner.

Does it have any problems?
========================
This is a very poorly done port. Horrible controls, no graphics options and the game has a lot more issues. You'll need to check out http://pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Darksiders if you have any problems.

Final Thoughts!
====================
A laughably boring main character, uninteresting plotline, and a steep learning curve for combat doesn’t help sell the game much. The boss fights are entertaining and the voice acting isn't a marvel. If you could enjoy, say, God of War, but without the storyline, characters, or great voice acting, then you could probably enjoy this game.

After 24 hours of gameplay finishing this game has become a chore and not very rewarding. The upgrades become stale and not worth the playtime at endgame. I'm already thinking of starting Darksiders 2 without finishing the first.

This game reminds me of the  God of War series with almost identicle gameplay and graphics style.
It has a good story about a war between Heaven and Hell,and is fun to play.Originally released for Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3 in January 2010.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=350473673
You play as War, one of the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse.As the story goes,someone Disturbs  the balance between Heaven and Hell and War gets the blame. The Horsemen are supposed to only be Summoned when The appropriate Seal for each Horseman is broken, although  something summons War without breaking the Seal that summons him.

Gameplay-Hack and Slash button combos,when you do enough damage to a foe an input prompt (B) for a finishing move will pop up over their head. You hit the button and it kills the enemy with a short animation.

Darksiders provides about 15 hours of single-player content.I've been playing 20+ There's lots of gear to collect, weapons to upgrade, combos to learn, and special items to find.

This seems to be from the era when games were still fun
before online multiplayer FPS flooded the market and  all of the Developers pumped out  mostly FPS's, I wish DEV's would return to making more games like this.
-Anyone out there remember any cheat codes?

reviewText:
Coming from Dark souls, the combat in this game feels MUCH MUCH more boring. Basically, with the sword, you spam (X), and occasionally, whenever you fancy you can hold (X) to do an artorias flip.  And even with the tweaks and a controller the input feels incredibly laggy and inresponsive, which makes dodging enemy attacks very frustrating. You'd figure that in an 'action' game at least the actions will be good, but apparently this is not the case.

Anyways, if you get it from a bundle by all means try it out for yourself but I wouldn't recommend this. I'm probably not going to finish this either cause there're much better games out there.

Also, terrible PC port, NO ♥♥♥♥ING GRAPHICS OPTIONS AT ALL! You can only change resolution, V-sync and brightness, that's it. V-sync also doesn't work and you have to use the NVidia Panel.

reviewText:
Pros
+ Interesting Story
+ Solid Puzzles

Cons
- Incredibly Repetitive and Boring Gameplay
- Tedious Backtracking

If you got God of War and Zelda, mashed them together, and took out almost all of the good things from both, you get Darksiders. Everything in between the boss fights and the occasional puzzle is just plain boring and feels like a chore.

Final Score - ★★☆☆☆

reviewText:
When a game is good, I quit a round of playing it because I feel sated and find I had enough fun for now and should do something else.

When quite a bit of frustration and boredom builds up and makes me quit the game, I can not call the game a good game but only an OK gave.

When at some point I seriously consider either uninstalling the game because I just don't want to endure some BS anymore or search for a cheat online to get past a certain point [spoileri]Sandwormlevel...[/spoileri], the only thing I can say about the game is that it sucks.

So, in this case, the game sucks.

It's story may be good, the combat may feel great, it may be really fun to sometimes just slash up enemies, but there repeatedly are situations where I feel myself getting really annoyed.

At some points I looked into guides to do a certain part, at one point I even seriously searched for cheat codes, after I died several times in the same BS part and had to endure a video sequence which I couldn't skip and a minute of annoying gameplay over and over again.

I would have PAID for a cheat code that allowed me to fly.

In the levels where you have to ride AND shoot at the same time the controls are just horrendous, you can EITHER aim, OR evade the enemies OR control your horse, but you somehow would have to do everything at the same time, which just doesn't work at all.

When you aim you ride into the direction you aim, resulting in you suiciding right into the enemy.

When you try to ride while looking back your horse will just turn around most of the time.

The controls are just terrible.

I feel that the game producers have not even the slightest idea how to make a good game.

To me it seems they wanted to achieve a long playtime, but they did by having you run far distances and by forcing you to play the game twice in order to uncover every secret item.

Larger enemies are hard to beat not because they do anything special, they will just do a ton of damage and sometimes even kill you right away without you being able to do anything about it.

That, dear devs, is not how to make a good game.

A good game makes fights interesting and increases playtimre by having the fights against bigger enemies last longer and by giving the enemies attacks that have to be avaded but won't cost the player a major part of their HP if failed to evade.

Sadly the way Darkiders works is that you will suddenly die to high damage attacks because you can barely or not at all evade them.

Darksiders will have you face enemies with projectiles that you can't evade and which will sometimes do enough damage to kill you right away.

This will happen repeatedly.

And you will have to go into the same fight over and over again and you will be killed over and over again.

If the part is supposed to be even harder to beat, there will just be two of those enemies put into a room with you.

Yes, you can quick save, but that is complete utter b***s***.

When you quick save in a difficult part and die, the quick save is lost.

Nope, no saving and duing a short part to save again and so on.

You die, save is lost.

I couldn't get a bigger punch in the face.

I also don't have the feeling that I beat the game by having skill"
date: I beat it by repeatedly abusing an item to stun large enemies so they won't kill me with one or two attacks.\n\nThat
hoursPlayed: makes at least me quit the game in frustration and boredom."

reviewText:
Darksiders is an action-adventure, hack and slash game. You're gonna be playing as War, one of the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse. The art style is probably the best thing about this game, Joe Madureira and the team behind him did an amazing job, even though it lacks on the technical part. The only things that I didn't like about Darksiders are definitely the performance issues that I encountered while playing. Crashes, lag, controller problems, limited graphical options and some bugs. But that didn't hurt my experience very much because the game is simply amazing. I loved the voice acting (Mark Hamill, Liam O'Brien and Troy Baker) it really helps the overall atmosphere of the game and adds a lot of credibility to the characters.
War is one of the most badass protagonists in a video game that I've ever seen btw.
As I previously said, the graphics are not spectacular but the art style sometimes makes me just want to stare at the screen for a few minutes.
This game borrows a lot of mechanics from different games like God of War, Tomb Raider, Prince of Persia, Devil May Cry, Zelda and so on. At first I didn't really like it but about 3 hours in, I realized it does this very well and Darksiders is actually quite an unique title because of the story and the overall feeling and style of the game.
Darksiders is an amazing adventure with a lot of really well made hack and slashing, puzzles, backtracking, platforming, even flying, swimming, searching for chests and collectibles and using your different tools/weapons that you aquire along the way.
It's one of my favorite games ever so I recommend it. The game took me about 17 hours on easy difficulty. Now I'm starting a new walkthrough on Apocalyptic difficulty. So basically, if you don't mind the performance issues you will enjoy this game a lot and you will definitely want to play the second one. If I'd give Darkisders a rating it would probably be a well-deserved 8.5.

reviewText:
Darksiders is an action adventure hack'n'slash type of game. You play as War, one of the Four Horsemen. Not  a lot known is about the Horsemen, they're meant to bring the Apocalypse, so this game has an interesting take. The story isn't bad, it's very likable but perhaps a bit forgettable in the end. I felt like I was more enjoying the gameplay than the story itself. You don't really get to know the main character, which makes it harder to connect to him.

The gameplay is a blast and very much alike God of War/Devil May Cry. Combat is enjoyable and you have different abilities that you can buy/upgrade. It has a lot of platforming. You have different weapons, some of them can level up. You also use your weapons to solve puzzles. The puzzles are clever and not that hard to solve, a lot of them involves timing. The game also has a few references that you might find familiar. The first real big boss can be a pain in the ♥♥♥ but once you get past you will see that the rest of them are easier.

The game is meant to be played with a controller so I can strongly advice you to play with one. However, aiming with ranged weapons are a bit harder with a controller and can complicate things along the way. If you find yourself having trouble with aiming then I suggest that you use your mouse and keyboard when needed.

The art style is very fantasy-esque. The game looks good and plays good. The voice acting is pretty okay as well. It's a little outdated by now but it still looks rather pretty. The bosses are huge and they look pretty awesome, it's very satisfying to take them down!

I really liked this game and can warmly recommend it, it has a few frustrating parts but none that really ruins the experience. It's not a long game but it's not very short either.

reviewText:
Darksiders gives off a very strong Legend of Zelda vibe with explorable enviroments, various different weapons (used to solve puzzles) and a strong storyline. I'll talk about each of these briefly in this review.

The graphics in Darksiders are surely not top notch, but they have a style i personally enjoyed greatly. The enviroments are beautiful, the characters (while horribly over the top) are memorable and the soundtrack is decent. Not top notch, but good enough.

The gameplay is pretty straightforward. See creature -> swing sword at creature -> creature dies. However, in its simplicity lies its greatest weakness. Fighting enemies quickly loses its appeal, since you don't have to think about it too much. Just swing, dodge attacks from some of the stronger enemies, and you're good to go. You unlock a wealth of alternative and upgradeable weapons throughout the game, but to be honest, all of them fail to improve on what your sword already does. They are, in general, so weak that there's no point using them outside of puzzle solving. Especially once you get certain unlockables, the sword vastly outdoes anything else you'll find, adding to the tedium.

Now, the story... The story actually delivers. You are War, arriving on earth to witness to apocalypse in progress, only to be called back in the middle of combat to answer for starting the apocalypse too early. What follows is an entertaining tale of betrayal and redemption (though admittedly, it does not nearly have the substance that Darksiders 2's story had, and the pacing is fairly slow until you start nearing the end).

In short, if you're looking for a game that will entertain for a week or so, Darksiders may be worth picking up. While it certainly has its appeal, it won't do more than that.

reviewText:
I heard quite a lot of good rumors about this game, but when I started I was bit skeptical. I didn't know that the game actually takes place in modern world, I thought that it would be fantasy settings, nor I am fan of bending traditional mythology. But it wasn't that bad after all, can't say the same about Thor movie which ran on TV 2 days before I wrote this. God, it was awful and not only because of lot of lore inaccuracies...

Basicly it's hack&slash with some rpg elements. You kill enemies who will kindly hand you their souls and for these you buy items, moves and few spell. Since it is a simple port UI is bit limited, there is about 6 item in game but you can only slot 3, and if you want to use different ones you have to open inventory drag them to quick-slots, which is cumbersome. Also you can't cast spell with a single key you have to use two >.< . I tried playing with the controller but I quickly came back to good old mouse&keyboard, since in my opinion it's easier to play this way, I found it hard to execute dashing attack with controller not to mention aiming is much quicker with mouse.

Story is decent even though it was mildly confusing for me until certain point. Also at first I thought they used names Abbadon and Destroyer simply because they couldn't thought about more cool sounding and fitting names, since both means the same,  but that cleared up near the end of the game. But well, if it was supposed to be the twist, then it wasn't.

Anyway, after my skepticism faded I had quite a good time with the game. And I can honestly recommend it.

PS: Warning for achievement hunters! The game has problems with steam achievements and you may not get ones you normally should. reviewText:
It's not as fun as it should be, somehow.
It feels too superficial, there's not enough power behind hitting things. You don't see and feel them getting hit as hard as they should be getting hit, when swinging a huge sword at them.
You should play Dark Souls instead of this.

I know the game may look just amazing and really cool upfront, but as you play it you'll find it doesn't deliver on everything you'd hope out of it.
Also there's too much puzzles and boring time-wasting stuff.
I came to be a bad-♥♥♥ and hit people with a large weapon, not to open chests and climb along walls to pull levers.
And you end up wishing boss fights were more epic than they end up being.

It's not what you'd hope it is, or at least what I had hoped it would be.

reviewText:
TL;DR: Good game, not perfect. Combat is a bit clunky. I preffer combat style of Batman games much more.

So, Darksiders. Well, I finished the game, so that's already a big endorsement, however I definitelly wouldn't say that Darksiders is a perfect game.

The combat is passable. I seriously don't understand the decision to put dash and block on the same button. That's just stupid. I played the game with a controller and I had huge trouble blocking attacks, either the block wouldn't register, or I dashed. I wish there was no aiming involved when a controller is the perefrable input device (however one of the bosses explicity requires aiming).

Boss fights are varied, but I would appreciate the bosses to be slightly easier to figure out. I got frustrated and checked the wiki for one boss fight and one mini-boss fight (then the fight became trivial).

The visuals are great. It's a console port, so the textures pretty bad, but the visual presentation definitelly makes up for the grafical fidelity deficiencies.

The story is pretty captivating and well written.

Overall, I would say that playing this game was a good experience (perhaps a bit too long for what it was). I would recommend this game (especially due to it's age resulting in low price), but I definitelly don't rank it anywhere near the top.

reviewText: Darksiders does a really good job of mashing together a hack-and-slash combo-based brawler with a typical dungeon crawler.  The story isn't awful, and the swordfighting combos feel very satisfying to execute.  There are some moments that are super-annoying (like running from giant sandworms in sand that disables your running/jumping abilities), but it's nothing completely detrimental.  All in all, a good game for the $20 value, even moreso if you catch it on sale.  A great title to break in your Steam account for Big Picture, too - I highly recommend using an Xbox 360 controller.

reviewText: Darksiders is a masterpiece. The puzzles and game mechanics are almost as good as in Zelda (although not quite ...), but what really pushes it ahead of other Zelda clones and even some of the Zelda games is the fantastic setting and characters. I loved how beautifully desolate the world was and how they focused on a small number of powerful NPCs to reinforce the desolation. It made perfect sense to only interact with demonic lords, angels and powerful magical creatures, because on the post-apocalyptic earth everyone else dies fast.

reviewText:
When this game game out, pc gamers finally got the third person, puzzle solving, hack and slash game we deserved all these years. dont let the possibly slow beginning push you away. give this game a good 30 minutes and you shant regret it!

a very nice variety of weapon customization, brilliant puzzles that progressively increase in difficulty to ease you in on it, great battle combos, interesting voice acting and story telling, AND THE BEST ENDING IN A VIDEOGAME I HAVE EVER EXPERIENCED. the ending had me daydreaming for a sequel, and we got a very deserving one!

textures seem a little outdated, but not nearly enough for me to complain about it, although some people might consider this a negative.

when you finish this game, and finish the second one as well, your mind will be blown in how the story is told. the two games are linked in  such a special way, that just kills me inside, thinking of the fact that we might not see a third installment in the series

voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I'm not a big fan of the slasher/puzzle type games, and Darksiders is no different.  Currently still playing, I find the game way too long - one that should have ended with the defeat of Straga; yet I am still traversing all the levels again looking for the armageddon sword.

However, there are many good things worth mentioning about Darksiders (opinions set aside) :
- challenging game play, even on easy setting
- tonnes of action, puzzles range from easy to difficult
- lots of jumping and exploring
- great graphics, especially the big bosses
- love the premise, heaven/hell join forces to battle evil

Minus :
- camera clipping issues
- sometimes jumps must timed right or you die - leads to frustration
- I tried with an 360 controller, and once it is plugged in, the game will only recognize the controller.
- would have been nice to include some rpg elements that upgraded the character instead of fight moves
- reminded me alot of God of War, especially when climbing on the demon growth


The only reason why I am not recommending this game is because I am not a fan of the slasher/puzzle/jumping around type game.  If you are, then Darksiders is well worth a shot.  If not, pass this one up.
