reviewText:
* Plot
Don't want to spoil to much but here's a little about the story
Very fun third person hack & slash game where you play as guy with anger problems that constantly talks as if he needs to take a ♥♥♥♥. His name is War. A battle between Heaven and Hell is waging on earth. You are the balance, sent to earth to return the world years after the apocalypse and restore the world to its original shape. The Destroyer, who is the one responsible for the war between good and evil. You need to defeat him to stop it. The plot was vague to get ahold of in the beginning but gets clearer towards the end. Worth finishing the game for. Story rated 7.5/10

* Weapons & Combat
Combat reminded me alot of God of War. In Darksiders it was a little too much left mouse button spamming for me though. You had some abilities to attack larger groups for example. Or deal damage over time. I could live with it and play with it. The combat is brutal at times with gory finishing moves. Especially on boss fights. In the stats tab there's also the amount of demon blood you've shed, indicated with gallons. Pointless but unique and fun to show how much you've slain. But I would've love to see something like a stun attack or something that temporarily gave you a shield or strength bonus. There's a couple weapons you will unlock while progressing through the game. For fighting foes, you'll mainly use your trusty sword Chaoseater. Other weapons that you'll unlock will help you to gain access to new places where you can find health upgrades for instance. What lacked in my opinion is gear to collect that add bonuses to health, armor etc. Before realising it I already stuck alot of hours in this game and couldn't stop finishing it. I first finished it on normal and I later tried beating the game on the hardest difficulty (Apocalyptic) as fast as possible and enjoyed playing it again from the start. I had alot of fun with this game. 8/10

* Graphics & Environment
Graphics look a tad cartoonish but doesn't hurt, you're busy fighting hordes of enemies anyway instead of admiring the graphics. The thing that dragged my attention the ruins of the apocalypse that you got to see as you played through each level. I really loved the matching environment added to the gameplay and story. It was combined very well. Truly, a hell on earth. Lastly the puzzles were fun and often hard to figure out. After beating the puzzles finally, they seemed pretty easy and were even easier to memorize. 9/10

Overall: 8/10[/b]

reviewText: I AM NOT DONE WITH THIS GAME. I plan on finishing it but heres what I think so far. I think this game is great, the graphics have an art style comparable to borderlands but not quite as cartoonish. The combat can be a hack and slash but you can do that or play like I did and master moves and combos rather than spamming one combo like U probably did with GOW. The enviorments are huge which was a pleasent surprise as I expected this game to be super linear. The RPG elements are awesome you'll be buying moves upgrading buying items and buying abilities, finding upgrades and so much more. I don't want to spoil the story but so far its acceptable. HOWEVER this is a console port so there are problems with this game. DO NOT buy unless your sure your graphic card can run this at a framerate you like (my prefered is 60) there aren't any fps drops but this game besides some resolution options has no graphics options whatsoever AND DONT YOU THINK about alt tabbing in this game because it distorts some effects like the scythe and also creates blocky shadows veryifying local gamecache did not fix this and a reinstall did. The cutscenes run in 30 fps and some textures look bad. Honestly this is a great game and if you are like me and can handle not alt tabbing and can run this game at 60fps (or whatever fps your comfortable with) than I highly recommend this game but if you just can't deal with that than either pick this up on consoles but after all the problems if you have the good fortune to run this 60fps  on PC I'd recommend that with the problems and all."

reviewText: Imagine God of War, except with 300% more puzzles and 200% less combat. This game has incredibly tedious puzzles paired up with repetitive combat. You'll come to learn that enemies lack dynamic mechanics to where it's nearly just a hack and slash and puzzle game thrown together. Throughout the game you will always find yourself doing puzzles more often than you are fighting enemies, and when you do fight enemies its the same 2 enemies reskinned. Did I mention that the story is just packed with loads and loads of puzzles? The game also gives you 5 items to do said puzzles and you will use all 5 throughout each area when you get them all. However you can only hotkey 3 of the 5 and have to go inside the ingame inventory to hotkey the other item just to have to re-hotkey the item you just un-hotkeyed to use the item you needed for the last puzzle. It had a lot of potential with story but the story just felt dragged out and the only reason why i play the game is because I feel like I'm getting closer to the end, but then they just throw in more and more paths filled with more and more puzzles. I'm 12 hours into the game and I finally felt like I was nearing the end boss when they threw in a completely new zone without ever being mentioned in the game prior and gave me a new item that lead to an incredibly boring fight and seemingly more boring puzzle mechanic. Overall it really isn't as good of a game that you hoped it to be and it I don't even want to complete the game because of how much of a chore it feels like.

reviewText:
Let me start this off to say that I haven't finished this game yet because it has been crashing, bugging out and glitching left and right.
I once had a bug that after I alt tabbed the projectiles, particle effects and War's animation speed doubled/triped with his movement remaining the same.
Once it looked like I had created a wormhole at the upper-left side of my screen destorting nearly 80% of the screenspace.
Another time I had my character going fully invisible with only the outlines of his weapon being visible. These and many more coupled with the occational crashes to desktop really prompted me to write this preemptive review and warn others who can't really deal with crashes.

That said, I will be finishing this game and updating my review unless the amount of crashes remain the same. Other than that, the content of the game itself is extremely well done. The combat is spectacular with the apocalyptic difficuly being reasonably challenging if not on the easier side.

Edit: I've had a few crashes here and there again, but the story has picked up its pace so I'm enjoying it a hell a lot more than the middle sections of the game.

reviewText:
This isn't really a bad game (it's actually a competent game), but it's such a generic-feeling action adventure game that it's really not worth your time when there are far more interesting games to play.

Story and enemy design is astoundingly boring, and combat is just mashing the attack button, occasionally using a magic spell if you get surrounded or turning into an invincible badass for 15 seconds once you build up enough charge.   Every once in a while things are made interesting with getting a horse or a huge cannon for a bit, and exploring hard to find areas is fun.

The puzzles are just awful late in the game.  You get a portal gun which is a direct copy of Valve's Portal Gun, except the puzzles are frustrating and not intuitive.  Half the time you don't know what you need to be doing with the gun, or where you need to go.

God of War is far superior to this, and although I haven't played many games of this type, I'm sure there are better options.
voteText: 26 of 54 people (48%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
I really wish this were better than it is.

Negative first (since you're reading this to know why I voted it down)
It's a fairly shoddy console port. Controller-oriented menus, few graphical options, shoddy mouse and keyboard control. With a controller, it handles decently, whereas some battles are literally impossible to complete with the mouse and keyboard controls
It has both fatal [CTD] and non-fatal [restart from checkpoint] bugs that are quite frustrating to say the least
Poor level and mechanic design. These vary from small and numerous (issues with engine-based input/action/animation lag, poor mechanical decisions, getting stunlocked to death, innappropriate or inadiquate checkpoint locations, etc.) all the way to compounded and quit-worthy (I stopped when I reached a miniboss that could take half my health in one hit, did an attack that covered 95% of the arena, and would knockdown for a second or even third invariably fatal hit after the first connected)
A feeling of Jack of all trades
recommended:
it tries to do too much. It's a combo-heavy hack 'n slash with puzzles and platforming, an RPGesque level-up system, and collectables that are actually key to survival. There is so much that you forget half of it even exists, so there were battles it took me an hour to figure out because they relied upon a mechanic I forgot about. None of the above are fully polished, and there are many hiccups, especially in the platforming and puzzling, where little to no direction is given, and the level design is not good enough to guide you through naturally.
This game is like a tutorial on how NOT to make boss fights. Take heed, game designers - these are inventive bosses with some of the most abysmal execution and unfair feeling losses I have ever seen in a game. They're not outright broken most of the time, they're just so unfair or punishing for the tiniest mistake that they echo the Famicom era of game design - play it over and over until you memorize it and time every move perfectly.

On the plus side:
The models and art, including the voice and music portions are nicely polished most of the time. Cutscenes were well done, the characters are well acted, and animations are polished. The story is fairly trite, but I expected no less

reviewText: Darksiders is perhaps a good game, but by no means a great one. However, this poor port from the consoles to the PC is perhaps the most damaging aspect of the game. So damaging that I find myself unwilling to endure it long enough to finish it. To start things off, a Windows update from early June of 2013 has made any video/CGI portion of the game unbearable. The top half of all of these sequences is nothing, but black. While many are quick to blame MS for this bug, I am not. The reason being that every single game I own, older and newer than Darksiders, is unaffected. Only Darksiders is affected, which leads me to put most of the blame squarely at the feet of the now defunct developer. And the grand-daddy of them all are the controls. They are downright terrible for the PC version. In the beginning you can easily manage to customize your mouse and keyboard in a way that makes the controls bearable, but as you progress throughout the game and gain new abilities you will find yourself agonizing over trying to find a new way to customize you controls all over again in a way that will work. Also, Steam offers only partial controller support for the game, so the only way to use one effectively is the tedious programming through a third-party program. Perhaps if the gameplay was a little more in-depth rather than hack and slash then it would be worth it to put up with these flaws. Alas, it is not. Other features that seem to be lacking is the freedom to move around the world, and the lack of an expansive world at that. I never finished the game, but considering that the game is just only 12-15 hours long, and that I got a quarter of the way through it, I would think that it would begin to open up in some more ways. If it does open up later then I doubt you will have much time to delight in it. There are some bright spots, however. Much of what this game takes after is The Legend of Zelda franchise. The puzzles, the dungeon-like settings, and whatnot are all there. But the game doesn't do much else to differentiate itself in a positive fashion. The puzzles are too simplistic (much more than the recent 3-D Zelda games), and the world is not nearly as expansive as Twilight Princess or even Ocarina of Time. It may sound unfair to compare Darksiders to the granddaddy of all adventures franchise, let alone Ocarina of Time, the highest rated game in video game history. But if one is to compete then they must offer something exclusive or something better. The only areas where it pulls it off is the secondary-attack weapons. But other than that there is nothing but cheap QTE-like finishing moves, and tons of blood to cover-up its obviously dated gameplay, even for the standards of 2010 (the year of release). The lack of decent controls on PC, the video problems on PC, the dated mechanics, and the lack of an open and compelling world doomed this game from potential greatness to okay.

reviewText:
This game is a masterpiece with incredible art, amazing sound and excellent gameplay.  For the PC however, it does not run well.  I've seen similar problems on many forums, that the game is not optimized for PC and so runs much, much higher than recommended 3MB of RAM and suggested Radeon graphcs card.
My computer has four times the necessary RAM and a graphics card that is more than double the power of the listed and still the cutscenes stutter, audio goes out and has all the symptoms of a very low end PC running a very high-end game.  My computer runs games like Crysis and Skyrim with little effort and yet cannot run this game. :P
I have not had this issue with the second Darksiders on PC, just this one.  I'm not sure if there is an intended fix for this but, I would not recommend purchasing this for PC, play it on Xbox 360 or your PS3 (if you have either of those) instead.
1/10 for PC - 10/10 for any other system. ;)

reviewText:
I've tried to get into this game on two separate occasions now, and it just doesn't hold my attention. It feels a lot like God of War, but it's not quite as exciting. The abilities you gain along the way aren't all that useful from what I've encountered, and you'll probably find yourself button-mashing your way through most fights.

When gameplay is less than fantastic, I usually turn to the story to save the experience. The story seems interesting, but the stoic main character is not really a protagonist that elicits any sympathy from me, and I feel no sense of satisfaction when I further the plot. I'm honestly struggling to write this review because I just don't remember much of the game.

It's not bad, and, if you've never played God of War or even Devil May Cry or the Batman games, you'll probably enjoy it. Otherwise, I would pass on this. It's just kind of meh.""

reviewText:
Do not buy this game, here's why:
Bad port. Clunky controls, limited graphic options, often awkward camera and my personal favorite a dead mouse. Obviously this port was made for quick cash in.
You will run into a technical problems. Once you try to turn on the game it welcomes you with black screen which requires you to delete some files from game directory or restart steam. Achievements won't unlock until you restart steam and you are never certain if you are going to unlock them or not. Save file might dissapear when you're half through a game.
Sound freezes for no reason durring cutscene.


Other than technical failures it feels like some soul-less executive in a expensive suit came into a game dev office, ditched five most successful games over last 5 years and ordered to frankenstein it together because it's guaranteed to sell. It doesn't have soul of it's own and often feels stale and boring compared to other games. It rips off portal, god of war, legend of zelda and adds nothing new.
It'll fit perfectly in my buyers remorse category.

reviewText:
A great story, with good characters, almost ruined by a game.

I want to love this game.  The story is engaging, I keep saying 'I want to know what happens next.'  You are a horseman of the apocalypse, which for some reason in the universe of this game are the guardians of the balance between heaven and hell.  Well someone messed that up, destroyed all mankind, and framed the rider War for screwing everything.  You are War, find the party responsible, make them pay.  Lots of twists and turns on that path, you'll honestly like a few demons, give others the finger, and laugh with glee while gunning down angels.
The visuals are impressive, remember all the World of Warcraft art with all the highly detailed armor?  Remember how that game looks nothing like that art?  This one does.  This looks like that.  This is the game that wanted to be visually.  Very pretty to look at, glorious in motion especially on PC without any framerate loss.

There are two problems.  First, they decided they wanted to make a puzzle platformer.  Wonderful bits of swordplay are interrupted by seriously overly long puzzle sections of tedius boredom.  Hope you like backtracking!  Seriously, you are forced to backtrack an absurd amount, and sometimes the path to where you need to be gets very confusing.  Prepare for lots of frustration before you get to the next stabby bit.

Second, they decided they wanted to add tons and tons of stuff.  We're talking hey!  Giant sword!  Cool, now give him a killer boomerang thing!  Awesome, but how about a gun?  Can we give him a gun?  Awesome!  But you know every good hero has a grappling gun, give him one of those!  Coded!  Great!  Now hey... There's this game called portal, maybe we should play with portals too?  BAM!  Portal gun added!  Sooo....  Let's drop the bass, give this guy a literal warhorn too!  A little odd but, done!  Now quests for collectables that require backtracking to every single game section after you acquire all this stuff!  Not to say how annoying it is to try to use it all in combat.

The controls are a little iffy, the camera likes to do perspective changes while you are trying to do percise platform jumping, which is a bit maddening.  Thankfully the game is very forgiving of the inevitable falls into endless pits, a small health penalty and puts you right back where you were this time knowing what the camera is about to do to you mid jump.  For the non platform sections?  Controls work fine.  With two exceptions.
1.  The game really needs a 360 controller.  The complicated mess of all the STUFF they want you to do is incredibly awkward on a keyboard.
2.  The range weapon controls are beyond terrible.  Going into aim mode makes you turn slower than molasses, and you need to hit things moving at full speed.  Makes you very thankful to get back to bashing things with your giant sword.

Then there is the purchase new combos option, which most tend to fall into two categories.  Too time consuming and or difficult to trigger mid combat, or way too easy to tigger mid combat so you're always going moves that take you in a direction you didn't want to go.  Thankfully the devs made the game smart enough not to let you fly off a cliff because you were doing a combo.  So go for the ledge fights, just keep well clear of the jump button.

One more note is stability.  The windows port is known for crashing.  But there is no pattern to this, all gamers report crashes at different spots with really no perdictibility.  In my experience I've had something like 6 game crashes in 13  hours.  I would say 3 were alt-tab related.  I also had a 4 hour flawless session that spawned multiple levels.  So be prepared, you will lose progress time to time.

The recommend yes/no system is a bit too limiting, I'd put this game at 75%.  Not enough to tell everyone to go get it, but if you want lots of puzzles with your hack and slash then pick it up.

reviewText:
WARNING WARNING WARNING - IF YOU ARE AN ACHIEVEMENT HUNTER DO NOT BUY THIS GAME

First off I will say that this is a fun and challenging game.  If you were to look at my profile you'll see I'm over 40 hours playing it.

So why the negative review?  One huge flaw:  The game has some magor bugs.  Bugs like sometimes acheivements don't get unlocked.  IF YOU ARE AN ACHIEVEMENT HUNTER DO NOT BUY THIS GAME.  PERIOD.  It is incredibly frustrating to play hours of a game hunting for all the acheivements to find all that work was useless due to some bad programming.  In my experience, about 50% of the time the achievements do not unlock.  50%!

If you're lucky and you had some previous save files so you can go back and spend an additional couple hours hoping that the acheivement will unlock on your second time around.  If you don't have an old save file, back to a new game for you.   Wonder why I'm at 40 hours on a game that should have been about 20?  Replaying the same things hoping this time the acheivement will get unlocked.

I NEVER write reviews but this game is so frustrating that I had to write one to warn people.

Again: IF YOU ARE AN ACHIEVEMENT HUNTER DO NOT BUY THIS GAME

Hoping for an update to fix those bugs?  Don't hold your breath since the company that made these games is now out of business.

If you don't care about achievements than this is a great game in the style of God of War.  Play at your own risk.

reviewText:
Minus a couple of slow points, I enjoyed it.

Pros
--The story was fun and different
--The protagonist's character arc was a level lazer beam, but he's a bad-♥♥♥, so...
--The settings were not colorful, but they matched the situation well
--Music was decent
--Voice acting was good
--Many of the puzzles were challenging to solve and implement the solution

Cons
--Had some interface issues where if I alt-tabbed, the game would usually crash
--Had 20 earned achievements not unlock
--Controls were clearly based upon using a controller instead of keyboard/mouse
--THQ and Vigil games are no more as of 25 January 2013, so there will be no more support for this game.

Depends on your point of view
--Level design reminded me a lot of Metroid
--Shamelessly copied a lot of other games

Darksiders draws inevitable comparisons to Zelda and god of War. Its a shame that it is never as smart as the first or as satisfying as the second.

The combat in bland, simplistic, overused and repetitive. You cant properly mix weapons in combos, in fact, most combos are 1 button sequences like: X, XX or XXX. If you wana be a pro try holding X for a sec. Yeah...

Off course sometimes you also have to dodge, but considering how much the enemies telegraph you their attacks I can say you almost have time to check your email. And don't let me start on the finishing" animations
date: so frequent and repetitive that got me tired of them after 1 hour of game.\n\nOverall the flow of the game is very contrived. A lot of it feels like filler
recommended: especially the underdeveloped platform segments. To make worst

reviewText:
I really, really, really wanted to like this game. Within the first five minutes killing angels by throwing cars at them? AWESOME!

What I got to play of it was very entertaining and exciting. The combat was a blast. The visuals for its age, were dynamic.

Then I came across a jumping puzzle and while I know *how* to do it--I *cannot* do it. The dexterity required was beyond my capabilities even when I tried with k/m which is difficult for me. To be clear, I can get by in Batman games and suchlike so it is plausible for devs to tame this down on easy mode.

On easy" mode [I test all games on that] the platforming puzzles do not scale down in relation to the difficulty
date: or scale down enough in difficulty. The combat does--the precision required to do those puzzles does not. I tried this specific puzzle more than 200 times and could not do it.\n\nI recommend this game IF you are not cognitively or physically struggling. It's lots of fun
recommended: for what it is.\n\nI cannot however
hoursPlayed: recommend it for anyone with challenges due to the precision nature of some of the jumping sections unless you want to frustrate the crap out of yourself. I'm still stuck at that broken down church and the rest of the game is now unplayable for me.\n"

reviewText:
Darksiders draws inevitable comparisons to Zelda and god of War. Its a shame that it is never as smart as the first or as satisfying as the second.

The combat in bland, simplistic, overused and repetitive. You cant properly mix weapons in combos, in fact, most combos are 1 button sequences like: X, XX or XXX. If you wana be a pro try holding X for a sec. Yeah...

Off course sometimes you also have to dodge, but considering how much the enemies telegraph you their attacks I can say you almost have time to check your email. And don't let me start on the finishing" animations
date: so frequent and repetitive that got me tired of them after 1 hour of game.\n\nOverall the flow of the game is very contrived. A lot of it feels like filler
recommended: especially the underdeveloped platform segments. To make worst
hoursPlayed: most puzzles feel uninspired and tedious
voteText: riped off directly from zelda games

but without the same level of polish in its execution.

There is constantly something gating your progress that don't feel like it was needed and the ways you solve problems always sound like they took triple the time they should have taken.

Its not terrible

reviewText:
I will write this having in mind that we live in 2016+

Is this Fable? No
Is this Zelda? No
Is this Devil May Cry? No
Is this Prince of Persia, Tony Hawk, Spiderman? Nope

This game is a clone of many different games and it's easy to see that for many people. Don't get me wrong - it's a solid game, there were no bugs, game goes smooth even on notebook, cinematics looks nice for the date of release (and for now), but... It is more like Soul Reaver (puzzle) mixed with something like ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ version of Devil May Cry (button smash).

In short:
Go from A to B, bring N parts of X, kill Y,Z, go back, return back, blablablah
Don't expect anything except objectives driven by half minute cutscenes, if you like a good storyline, better don't play it because many interesting characters were just ignored - they have no background at all.

Now go kill satan and bring a beer

reviewText:
Let me begin by saying that my dislike for this game is based purely on a personal preference:
I HATE cartoony WoW-syle graphics. With an unreasonable, flaming passion.

What makes it worse is that the content of this game, a war between Heaven and Hell, virtually demands a dark and gritty atmosphere. Instead you get what looks like a war between Cartoon Network and Disneyland.

Is it a good game? Probably. Could I ever get immersed in it? Absolutely not.

reviewText:
If you enjoy religious folklore, pretty, and colorful, for its time graphics, action intetwined with puzzles and platform this game is for you.
I've played through it thrice, twice on PS3 and once on PC, and enjoy it immensly. The combat system is well developed, the weapons and combos are interesting and fun. Also, <3 Horse <3.

I've had a very positive experience playing the game, and would reccomend it to anyone.

Kudos Vigil games, lots and lots of Kudos.

reviewText:
People aren't joking when they say this is Zelda-like. Besides aiming mechanics and perspective it has everything up to and including chests, grappling hook, bottles, masks and even a shadow Link battle. In that regard it's pretty fun.

However this is an almost stereotypical crappy PC port. Random slowdown, cutscene skipping, horrible default keybindings and little room to customize them as well as other scattered bugs. Despite annoying me greatly I was still able to push through it and had many good moments. Which is why I'm not thumbing it down. Just keep in mind that you'll be seeing a lot of stuff in the vein of the following video I made.

Also, this comes with a comic and complete OST. The game takes it upon itself to install these things to your main partition without asking you though. I enjoyed the comic. It's pretty cheesy but then so is the game. I'm also a sucker for supplemental material like this.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wFtyhLyg27s

reviewText:
I'm 4 hours into this game and I'm just not having any fun.  It's not a terrible game, but it's pretty tedious.

First off, the story is intriguing enough.  I kinda wanted to know what happened.  Though the characterization is pretty weak.  Just about every character is a 1-dimensional ultimate badass type except the merchant, it's not horrible but not exactly great either.

The combat is reasonably entertaining.  There are basically two types of monsters so far, the ones you can hit stun, which you pretty much just beat up and are harmless, and the big ones you can't hit stun, which you dodge->hit->dodge-> hit.  Again, not terrible, not great either.

As with all over the shoulder console games, the camera pretty much follows behind you.  Hence to keep the camera focused on the big mob you need to dodge you have to hold L2/left trigger.  Personally find holding that button extremely awkward and wish the camera lock was a toggle, however there's pretty much no options in terms of changing controls.  Not a deal breaker, but annoying.

The platforming, wall climbing and switch hitting is tedious to the max.  Here's a room I just finished, slide down a rope, hit a switch, jump across 4 platforms, throw your batarang at a switch, jump across 2 more platforms, batarang switch, jump 2 platforms, grab a bomb, blow a thing up, jump some more platforms, batarang switch, jump more platforms, jump into a room, grab the grab here" effect on the wall
voteText: get a key
votesHelpful: jump some more platforms
votesTotal: hit a switch
votesFunny: jump 4 platforms
commentsCount: batarang switch
column16: jump more platforms
column17: into a room
column18: batarang switch
column19: jump out of the room back to the key hole to place the key.\n\nI'm sorry but that's not fun
column20:
that's a lot of busy work.  There's nothing in this game fun enough to compensante for tedious time wasters like that.

Worst of all is the controls for aiming ranged attacks.  Absolutely brutal.  I was using a gamepad as this is clearly a console game but I have read the mouse is no better even for the ranged attacks.

6/10"

reviewText: I would not buy this game or even attempt to play it through steam as they have done a terrible job of converting it. Not only can you not play it at a higher resolution but you must disable every security feature which include any active anti-virus, maleware protection and your firewall. It doesn't matter what your computer specs are there are no way to alter or reduce the demand of physical memory this game allocates to your system. In some cases if your save game file becomes too large it won't load, if you stop in a spot right before a boss fight and enter, it will freeze. If you try asnd summon either the watcher or Ruin your steed, it will freeze at times. This game is far too buggy and I regret buying it in the first place and of course it seems that steam is in no hurry to make any fixes to their products, as usual. So you can forget a fix in the future at any rate and the developers are under a new name and most likely will not provide any support for this game as it is a only a few years old.

reviewText:
The KB smashing and timing to perform jumps are really bad.  Obviously the game was never tuned for a Win platform.  I can't count the number of times I've tried to jump across ledges to end up just falling or miss a critcal hit

You should save often and if you switch to desktop expect a game crash when the next section of map is loaded.
I'm running Win 7 64-bit and of all the games I have this one crashes the most predictably.

Many times I'm at some level with no hint of what to do or where to go.  Thanks to youtube.
There are many areas in the map you think you can reach but can't.   Same goes to ledges.

Fighting is more clumbsy than Zero-Clash.  However, some of the characters and mini-bosses are interesting.  Art direction is good but game mechanics are lacking.

Aiming of range weapons and use of some special powers are awkward.  Such as press Cap lock" to bring up a menu then select a number all the while you are taking a beating from multiple bosses and smaller minions.   Why do you need a separate set of keys to rise and dive while swimming ?

There are many many times where I can't see the battle b/c the camera is stuck in  a wall or is gltichy.

Most of the time I spent in game is me switching over to youtube on hints of what to do next
date: otherwise I would have rage quick long time ago.  I never had to go to youtube for TombRaider

reviewText: let me first say that I got this game on my Xbox360 about a year ago and loved it. Having to go to college though required me to leave my xbox behind, so when I saw that this was on sale for  super cheap it was a no brainer to get this game. For the first part of the game I didn't really have problems with the game (except for the camera being pretty crap), but that all changed when I first got into a fight with a tougher enemy and kept getting my ♥♥♥ kicked. The problem being is that the controls are awful. It feels awkward trying to hold alt and move around to dodge enemy attacks, and the same goes for using special abilities. Which require you to hold CAPS LOCK and press 1-4. I also had a few times when I would enter a new area I would just fall into blackness, because the area didn't finish loading in the time I booted up the game and kicked through the door. The game also crashed on me twice so far. Once when I was right about to exit the game, and a second time in a middle of a dungeon. With all that being said I still personally love the game, but the PC version is just terrible compared to the console versions, so if you have a choice between the two get the console version. The controls just work better on it, and I never experienced falling into black pits of nothingness.

reviewText:
A boring reskin of God of War, with over 9000 cutscenes PER MINUTE. If you're still living in 2005, this is your game.

Action is boring. Just hold down X, and aim stick. Will auto-attack and destroy anything with escalating, showy attacks you don't even have to trigger.

My favorite part of it is how every major demon announces himself with an evil laugh. Doesn't matter if he's angry, helpful, an enemy, an ally. It's always: MUHAHAHAHA! Will you please do a fetch quest for me WAR?" That's some high-quality writing

reviewText:
Had on my backlog for ever, why didn't I play this before. An ARPG that is mixed with a bit of Street fighter but unfortunatly that problemative first 3d one that didn't quite work.

I started really liking this and there is a lot to like in the game, infact I did a review after 2.5 hours were I was very positive, since deleted.

It has good environments, interesting story, bit of platforming and the combat starts well. The trouble is that the combat is a bit clunky at times, not always the easiest to aim/attack who you want. So when you get to the first real hard boss it is just plain out frustrating and so I walked away.

Even some of the fights before that we not fun due to the clunky nature of 3d fighting done badly.

Shame as really wanted to like this

reviewText:
Darksiders had a lot of potential, but the series doesn’t fulfill it until the sequel.

Yes, the environment and characters are awesome, but this game doesn’t deserve the praise it has gotten. Why? Because it fails at being the one thing a game has to be: fun. As other reviewers have said, the longer the game goes the more tedious it becomes. The fights and exploration become long and boring and the game becomes a chore.

Pass and buy Darksiders II instead.

reviewText: Combat is fun at early stages but as time goes it start to feel repetative. There are numerous combat moves and to remember them all can take some time which can be quite hard with poorly implemented controls especially if you use mouse and keyboard. This game plays best with controller. Puzzle solving could be even more fun if not for dumb game mechanics which always tell you exactly what to do. Puzzles, while plentiful and occasionaly good, are tedious and unforgiving. At some stages camera angle is locked in place and limits your view which can be very frustrating. Story is above average, but nothing spectacular, dull main character combined  with poor voice acting that makes my stomach cringe. Art style, level design and character models are fantastic. My experience with this game is not that good.

reviewText:
Before I go into depth I want to specify that I did use a gamepad for this game - I strongly recommend using one and would go so far as to say to skip this title if you don't have one. It's a console port, guys.

Darksiders is a game that wears its inspirations on its sleeve famously, and to a ridiculous degree. When you're traveling through a Legend of Zelda-style dungeon solving puzzles with a Portal Device, you know you're not playing a game that's focusing on being particularly innovative.

That's fine, it doesn't do it does particularly well though.

The dungeons, level design wise, are all threadbare. Puzzles never get more complicated than get past the obstruction using the item you got in that dungeon"

reviewText: It's like God of War, except they took out 'God of' and kept 'War'. Basically, you mash the Attack button, and... that's about it. Your character's weapon is a huge 2-handed sword, but it doesn't even feel like it has weight, which makes combat feel unsatisfying. Slash weapons should be fast and interesting to use. Slow weapons should feel heavy but powerful, and every hit should be satisfying. It's not the case here. You can dodge, but it's really only useful during boss battles, which are usually just the same boring pattern 20 times. You can collect souls and buy things with them, but it kind of feels out of place and breaks the flow even more. A simple Skills or Upgrades menu would've been better. Also, I don't think there's any music in this game... and the visuals are a bit bland. Overall, I wouldn't recommend buying this game outside of the THQ humble bundle, unless you really love the genre.

reviewText:
Pros:
-Good graphics.
-Interesting concept.  You brawl against both devils and angels.

Cons:
-So many damn puzzles.  This guy shouldn't be the personification of War.  He should be the avatar of bored librarians with lots of free-time. You will be spending more time doing puzzles than fighting.
-Very poor console control to keyboard port. There is a part that requires you to hold a button to pick up an item while holding another button to aim. You do all this while trying to press more buttons to dodge the boss's attacks.
-Uninspiring weapons and special moves.
-Lots of backtracking across maps.
-Forgettable story line.

I thought I was going to play as the bad-azz embodiment of War, but instead I felt like a cartoonish kid in green tights out to save my girlfriend.

reviewText:
I felt like Darksiders did some things right but the main components of the game felt wrong. There are 2 aspects of the game which I think Vigil did right, and that is the sound (voice acting and music) and the art design. Both are well polished and interesting. War looks like a real badass and sounds like one too.

But this game is a 'hack and slash' so the combat should be the main focus, and this is where I felt the game fell short. It felt clunky and slow to put it bluntly. Blocking is extremely awkwards because the put the same button to block as they did dash when you're moving in a direction. So when trying to block you more often than not dash, which can result in you getting hit. And I hate getting hit. Juggling also ties into blocking with how enemies behave. Small things like a certain grunt enemy (which are plentyful) do a ground bash that somehow also hits you in the air, which it honestly shouldn't (I mean, it is a ground attack), causing you to lose your juggle as well as being unblockable. The lock-on system and free aim systems are both awful. When locking on it changes your camera angle so you frequently can't see what is behind you and it is also awkward trying to change between targets. Free aiming is exponentially worse. It is difficult to describe in words, but the aiming is slow, clunky, awkward, and so frequently used it makes for a terrible gaming experience. What's more is that parts when you have to hit something with your projectile weapons is made that much harder because the game forces you to use the free aim controls, instead of just locking on to what you need to hit. I think this is unecessary to the overall experience of platforming.

Manouvering the game world is also a chore in my opinion. Darksiders is a hack and slash, and world design in such games needs so be concise and straight forward, or in other words somewhat linear. Backtracking or having an open level design is fine, exemplified in Devil May Cry 4 for example. But Darksiders has a world designed more like and RPG than the traditional hack and slash and it is painful trying to navigate it. War moves rediculously slow, especially when you're just trying to move from A to B in a big, open space. Moving from area to area is more bearable with a quicktravel system, but that involves War walking from one portal to another in some ethereal space. It takes 2 minutes but it is rediculously tedious. There is absolutely no need for it.

My verdict is that if you can pick up both Darksiders I and II for 10 bucks or less, you can do worse for your money. But small nuances in the gameplay degrade the overall experience too much, and I believe if you want a better hack and slash game you should play Devil May Cry 4 or earlier (not DMC).

reviewText:
This game has its fun moments. The battle animations are cool and I always love to see games with strong art direction. Darksiders has been compared to Zelda and I would say that for the most part, that's a decent comparison. There are temples with puzzles and new weapons to collect and a big boss to fight at the end. It's a good formula.

But my problem with this game is that it's gratuitous. After slogging through one too many arena-style battles featuring wave after wave of enemies... it got old. I just wanted it to end. The level of violence in this game is pretty gruesome, and going into this game, I knew it was a stretch for me. Maybe some people get a thrill out of splitting enemies in half or ripping the wings off of angels, but again, this got tiresome and trite pretty quickly.

It also doesn't help that virtually every character in this game is some gravel-voiced dude whose character motivations, if they even exist, are hidden behind in-game fantasy jargon. It's been a while since I've played, but from what I remember, they have special names for all kinds of eternal creatures or gods or places, and after a while, I started forgetting who was who and why I should care. Most of the cutscenes could be summed up with listen to this deep-voiced guy say cool words." If it wasn't that
date: it was "watch this super muscular guy graphically slice up some enemies."\n\nSo if this what a Westernized version of Zelda looks like... I'll stick with the original

reviewText: Hmm... Where to start. The beginning really caught me. It was impressive for the most part with the combat. However, when you're intoduced to Samael, that's where the bore-fest begins. Think of finding all of the map pieces in Wind Waker + a lot of enemies and areas. By that point, the story is dropped to focus on this one event. You could call it a contributing point to the whole story but once you get to the ending (which is where the story starts again), you'll soon see that it could of been organized better. If you like 14hrs of hack & slash + a few puzzles (don't overthink the puzzles like I did), then sure pick up the game.

reviewText: I played this game on easy level for almost 9 hours. It's good game, even graphics is fine, story is decent, well the dialogs could be better but... So, maybe I am casual player, but in 9 hours of playtime I stuck on first miniboss in Chapter 1 Twilight Cathedral, The Jailer. Despite so many hours of trying to beat this boss I wasnt able to do so. I am sorry, but If a game on easy level is so difficult that player can't finish one of six chapter then there is something wrong with a game. I may be lame player, sure, but games should be fun not hardcore torture especially on easy level! So sadly I do not recomend this game as I wasnt able to finish it. :/

reviewText: This game is not up to the level of quality required for a PC game.  It's a console port that leaves much to be desired.   The control scheme is very clunky.  The camera controls are almost non-existent.  Keyboard and Mouse control, which is ideal for almost any gaming circumstance, has been poorly applied to this game.\n\nIf, however, you are craving a console gaming experience, but can't afford a lobotomy, Darksiders may be the crappy console port for you.   Press A to continue, or press X to remember you deserve better than this.

reviewText:
It breaks my heart to thumb down this because I love Joe Madureira and his work on Battle Chasers.

To be blunt, from artistic stand point the game is flawless, but then again art is made by MAD! so it's expected.

Combat is fast paced enough but what annoys me is they basically copy - pasted some moves/upgrades such as Nero's Devil Bringer (DMC4) or shameless Portal gun copy.

However the big weakness in this game lies in the fact it super saturated with puzzles, and I don't mean Soul Reaver 2 kind of puzzles, but bring that potato over there" or "slightly move this thing to go to the other thing that you must move"
recommended: there is no combat mixed between the puzzle pacing to break the mood
hoursPlayed: and the puzzles are repetitive at most  and lack of the rewarding feeling is sensed. It becomes really boring and I just know that new area == more boring puzzles... I really hate that

reviewText:
This game does a lot of things right. The combat is fun and does not rely too heavily on button mashing. The dodge There is a degree of skill needed to take down more powerful enemies without getting repeatedly killed or losing all of your health after one fight. The story isn't the most captivating, but it properly sets the tone and applies context to all of the action. Lastly, the art and design for this game are also excellent, evoking the fantasy of this realm. All of these factors should have combined to make a great game, but the frustrating puzzles are holding this game back.

The puzzles in this game are annoying for two reasons: they frequently involve backtracking through old areas rather than exploring new areas, and they ruin the action oriented pacing of the game. I try to avoid the Zelda comparison when talking about this game, but I can't help feel that Zelda is infinitely better at what this game is trying to do; particularly when it comes to blending the combat and puzzles. In Zelda, the combat is low-key, slow-paced and requires more decisive and timed hits (like a puzzle itself), so the puzzles keep the pace going evenly. This is different from the action heavy button-mash beatdown of Darksiders. There is nothing wrong with button-mash beatdown as a gameplay mechanic, but when I'm forced to take it slow and do a tiresome puzzle, what should be a healthy challenge becomes a tedious roadblock in my fun.

Writing this review made me sad because this game has a boatload of potential that was crippled by obnoxious puzzles. I don't recommend this game because the puzzles were more frustrating than the game was fun. If looking up a walkthrough isn't an assault on your pride then go ahead and get Darksiders, however there are not a lot of good ones for this game. As a closing note, I can't recommend this game, but parts of it were enjoyable enough for me to wonder if the sequel is better.

reviewText:
Formulaic, shallow character-action game. I felt as if I was playing a bad DMC game. The story itself is so uninteresting that it's not even worth mention here.
The puzzle goals are sometimes vague and always grind the pace to a halt. Frankly, this game was really boring for me.
The action was unremarkable. Combo, dodge, combo, repeat ad infinitim.
Hopefully the second one was better.

reviewText: If you are thinking about getting this game don't buy it. Save your money and time.\nThe story is quite confusing, first you spawn on a street and just start fighting enemys for no givin reason, then your in hell for some other reason and then a demon comes into the main characters arm.\nThe combat consists of just clicking or just running away but sometimes you can do a finishing move which is not that great. There is huge powerful creature you can turn into but you can only turn into it at the beginning of the game and I tried to turn into it at boss battles but it wouldn't let me.  There is one part in the game where it tells you to kill 500 enemies in a small space so basically you end up wasting your time finding a ton of enemies then killing them then you end up getting rid of them.  The last thing I want to say is the wings in the game.  When I first got them after I beat a boss I thought I could fly but they only allow you to jump more.  So overall you shouldn't get this game.
